INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) raised a point of order in relation to the matter of public importance, claiming that it breached the anticipation rule. Leaving aside the fact that a matter of public importance is not brought forward unless the Speaker has made a determination that it is in order, I want to say that we have a system of matters of public importance in this House which is quite different from that which has evolved in other major parliaments with which we have links such as the parliaments in the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand. In the House of Representatives discussions are held almost every sitting day and an important feature of them, in a general sense, is that they are of immediate and current public interest.

INTERJECT.PARA: In approving Friday's matter, which related to capital gains and fringe benefits tax proposals, I was well aware of the fact that there are Bills before the House which also relate to capital gains. Standing order 82 gives the Speaker a discretion in relation to the anticipation rule in that I have to take into account the probability of the matter anticipated being brought before the House within a reasonable time. In my view this discretion should be used in its widest sense where a matter of public importance is involved if our system is to continue in its present form. The possibility that the Bills may be debated later this week had to be weighed against the immediacy of the matter put forward for discussion. I intend to continue to exercise my discretion in respect of the anticipation rule, as it relates to matters of public importance, in a very wide sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Does he agree with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs who suggested a three-point plan to solve our trade deficit problems-increasing tax, limiting company takeovers and introducing value rather than volume quotas on car imports?

—There are a lot of views about how one ought to respond to the terms of trade problem. For my part-and I think I am reflecting the Government's view here-the building of quantitative restrictions on imports is not something which I would encourage the Government to do. I believe it would only further contract and diminish the quality of the multilateral trading system. A free and open system is in Australia's clear best interests. Therefore, this is not a prescription that I would adopt. On the more general point of the issues involved here, I believe that this is a long term problem that Australia has had and I have said this in the House on many occasions. I remind our colleagues in the Opposition that they had a 6 per cent current account deficit in 1981-82 and that the problem has been here for a long time with the decline in our traditional sectors, our lack of competitiveness through the 1970s and the loss of traditional markets. We have been used to importing goods which have been paid for by our exports. The fact is that now, to a lesser and lesser extent, our exports are paying for those goods and this requires internal adjustments which I am sure the Australian community well understands and appreciates.

—I address my question to the Minister for Aviation. I refer to the progressive international air freight policy implemented by the Government. Can the Minister inform the House how successful this policy has been and what results it has achieved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The issue he raises is one of very great importance to the far north of Queensland. He, along with the honourable member for Herbert, has been largely instrumental in pushing forward some of the principles that have been incorporated in that proposal.
—What about me?

—I was going to go on to refer to a Katter other than the one who has just interjected. The policy provides for primary produce charter flights and for mixed consignments to be shipped to any destination and for primary produce to be picked up from more than one of our smaller international airports. It provides also for outbound flights, as part of the overall journey, to be allowed to carry the high yielding inbound freight, which assists the revenue aspect of the charter flights. Livestock flights can also carry a mixture of primary produce and livestock on the outbound journey, and that has also enabled considerable expansion in available capacity.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to say to the honourable member and to the House that since the implementation of the new policy in November last year there have been some 65 flights approved. In those terms the policy clearly has been successful. It offers the greatest opportunity ever for primary producers to develop their external markets by the use of international air freight. One has to mention also that, once the excess capacity from inbound passenger flights is mixed up on inbound flights that carry other cargo, which is the higher yielding cargo, profitability depends upon the value of the product being exported and upon the type of freight that can be carried because effectively what is happening is that inbound high value freight is cross-subsidising outbound lower value freight.

As I have said, the policy clearly has been successful. It offers the greatest opportunity ever for exporters to develop new markets by the use of air freight. There is one aspect of it, however, which has been quite negative and which naturally has been promoted consistently by the National Party of Australia. I refer to north Queensland and to the actions of the Minister for Northern Development or, rather, I should say, the Minister for non-development in Queensland. That Minister has all the trappings of a ministry, all the money that goes with a Ministry. I am told that in the far north he has a staff of a public relations officer, a steno-secretary and an appointments secretary. It seems that his major role is to put down the efforts of progressive policies such as this air freight policy rather than to promote the genuine opportunities that are available to primary producers in the north. For instance, recently he made the claim that there has been some sort of deal between Qantas and Air Nuigini to prevent freight being carried out of Cairns to New Guinea. The fact is that there is an air service agreement between Australia and New Guinea. We approved the scheduling of cargo flights from Cairns to Port Moresby but that was subsequently rejected by the Government of New Guinea. That is its right. It is not something that was a decision of Qantas but rather it was a decision of the Papua New Guinea Government. In addition to that, he made the ridiculous statement that freight out of Brisbane and Sydney was cheaper than freight out of Cairns. The fact is that the rate out of Cairns is some 89c per kilo for uplifts of 250 kilos or more and $1.03 per kilo for uplifts of less than 250 kilos, whereas the rate out of Sydney or Brisbane is $1.25 per kilo. Along with the actions of the Minister for non-development in Queensland there has been, regrettably, action by some elements of the Townsville Daily Bulletin to highlight the negative approach put forward by the Queensland Government on air freight opportunities and to deny opportunity for statements to be made by this Government to update the policy announcements which have been made here on occasions by myself and by the local members. I draw the attention of the House to that fact. What has happened is that, because the Townsville Daily Bulletin and elements within it are denying the information that is available on the new policy, they are retarding opportunities for primary producers in the far north of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! If you want to make a statement, do so.

—I know that the right honourable member is not interested. His Party operated the most restrictive international air freight policy ever seen in this nation. This Government has done something about it. He is not happy with that. He and his Party want the primary producers of northern Queensland not to know about it. They do not want primary producers in the far north of Queensland to have the opportunities that are available. Just as the National Party has turned its back on the cane growers of Queensland, it is trying to turn its back on the primary producers in the far north who do have opportunities under the policies available from this Government. We are not going to go along with the National Party policy. The National Party is not interested in the people of Queensland. It wants to put them down, as it wants to put down the cane growers and primary producers of the far north of Queensland. The policies we are presenting and practising will provide the greatest opportunities ever for those producers to develop their export opportunities and markets in the period ahead.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Does the Government respect the independence of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and will the Government support the Commission's judgment when handed down in the national superannuation productivity and national wage cases?

—Of course the Government supports the independence of the Commission and respects its independence and its right to make the decision that it thinks fit. I regret that some statements I have seen recently from the Confederation of Australian Industry indicate a lack of preparedness by that body to have the same view as the Commission. It is deplorable when the chief employer body in this country, the Confederation of Australian Industry, says in a public statement at the weekend that, if employers do not get the decision they think appropriate from the coming wage decision, they will perhaps boycott the Commission in the future. That kind of reaction from what I would have regarded previously as a responsible body is deplorable. It comes from the hype that has developed about this case and the apparent desire of the CAI not to be seen to be weak by some of its more militant elements or perhaps by militant elements outside the CAI. I hope that it does not occur again. I stress that all parties should respect the right of the Commission to make the decision it sees fit and should live by and abide by that decision.

—Is the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services aware of complaints by local government in Tasmania concerning the new financial assistance arrangements for local government? Is the Commonwealth Government discriminating against local government in Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that there is some concern in Tasmania about the new arrangements for local government finance. Local government in Tasmania will continue to do well under the new arrangements. Local government in Tasmania in 1985-86 received $17.5m under the old Act. Under the new arrangements it will receive at least $18.3m in 1986-87, and at least $18.6m in 1987-88. I stress the words `at least' because these payments are geared to the States. In other words, there is an agreement that over the next two years local government will receive at least the same as the States, although it has been given a guarantee, unlike the States, that it will not get less than the previous year. These figures show that there will be no cut in funds to Tasmania. However, it is true that Tasmania's share of total funds will decline. This outcome is a reflection of the recommendations of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, and advice subsequently received by the Government. The inquiry recommended a review of State shares and suggested the involvement of the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The Grants Commission advised the Government that the results of such a review would not justify the time and effort involved. In these circumstances we took the advice of the National Inquiry that interstate shares should be equal to population shares. The Government has decided to phase in the new shares over a period of three years, so that adjustments can be made gradually in regard to the new interstate relativities.

ANSWER.PARA: There will be some criticism, and some States will receive less under these arrangements, but the solution on the whole is a good one. It is true that even New South Wales will receive slightly less than it does under the present scheme. The two States that will gain substantially out of this arrangement will be Victoria and South Australia. Let me stress, in a very tight budgetary context, that all members on both sides of the House know that local government has done particularly well. Local government is pleased that there is a continuity of untied funds not only in the next two years but over, at least, the next five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to use my right of reply to my good friend the Minister for Aviation. I address my question to the Treasurer. I refer to today's estimate by the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales that the fringe benefits tax on farm housing, produce and power alone will cost farm employers $152m per annum. In light of the Treasurer's statement on Friday that the Government is seeking to ensure that these taxes are not unduly harsh, will he revise the application of the fringe benefits tax to farm employers who are suffering record low real incomes, small businesses, small mining interests and all those involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now witnessing a lot of extravagant statements made about the fringe benefits tax by various industry groups. As I indicated during the week I do not see the tax being a burden in respect of farm employees for the reason that, if we are talking about the rental value of accommodation provided on farm, the level of rents is very low. Some are in the region of $40 a week-some may be more, many may be less. We take 60 per cent of that value, which would be some number in the 20s, less what is paid by the employee; and 49 per cent is charged on that. It may end up being only a few dollars a week. So it is not a burden of the kind that is reflected by the comments in the honourable gentleman's question. The other issue of concern which emerges here is that many homesteads are owned by companies. They were put in the name of companies at a time when death duties applied so as to minimise the death duties and enable the property to be transferred to members of the company rather than from a parent to children, and hence be subject to full duty. Some farmers who merely have their residence in the name of a company are concerned about whether they have to pay the fringe benefits tax on the value of the accommodation. The answer to that is no, they do not. The issue here is that the tax is levied only on the rental paid in respect of employment, not on the residence as such. Lest the concern may go, if you like, to the child of a farmer who may work intermittently on the farm, obviously housing for that child is provided because he or she is a member of the family and not because he or she is an employee.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, some farmers whose homestead has been in the name of a company may have been deducting the costs of their private residence against the company. In other words, deductions for paint, repairs or maintenance are not available to taxpayers for their own homes, but there could be a case where deductions have been taken by farmers for their households or homesteads in the name of companies, in which case they would be acting against the law. Of course, if that were happening the application of the fringe benefits tax on that homestead would be defensible. If that is a concern, I would suggest that it is something about which the people involved should examine their own taxation position.

To the more general point, let me repeat: If the Government under this rule takes 60 per cent of whatever is the rental value of the on-farm benefit to the employee and then taxes the amount at the rate of 49 per cent after the actual rental is deducted, it is not at a rate which should lead to the kind of concern implicit in the honourable member's question or the comment he offered by way of substantiation of the claims made by the Livestock and Grain Producers Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of Derryn Hinch's article carried in the weekend Herald calling for a bounty hunter to track down what he terms as welfare bludgers? Can the Minister inform the House of measures the Government has taken to detect overpayments and deliberate defrauding of the social security system and to preserve the integrity of the system? Can the Minister also comment on claims that social security overpayments have reached scandalous proportions and the use of the estimates described as `good sources' to substantiate those claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's question refers to Derryn Hinch's article in Saturday night's Herald. It is clear from that article that Hinch not only has a contempt for the courts of this country but also has contempt for millions of Australians who through no fault of their own have found themselves in financial difficulty. This highly paid spokesman for the average weekly earner--
—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order.
—Bounty hunter.

—If the honourable member will just hear me he might understand. The Minister may not be aware of this. On Thursday of last week the man referred to was found guilty of contempt by the Supreme Court of Victoria. He is awaiting sentence. The hearing is before His Honour on Wednesday in regard to sentence. I think that, by using words such as `contempt' and so on, the Minister is transgressing that hearing which is still before the court.
—Could I suggest that the Minister does not refer to the case again.
—I was not going to refer again to Derryn Hinch except to say that if he showed something of the same concern for the unemployed as he might expect for himself--
—Order! The Minister will leave the whole topic aside.

—Let me go to the substance of the question, which went to the Government's measures with respect to overpayments. During the last 18 months we have introduced a number of significant steps in this area. They have included a range of high technology, management and staff development procedures for the detection of fraud and overpayments. Rather than indulge in heavy-handed hysterical claims about dole bludgers and cynical single mothers, this Government has done more than any other to tackle the overpayments issue and to ensure that its resources go to those most in need. Even our greatest critic, Peter Sawyer, author of the yet unpublished manual Dole Bludgers for Beginners, concedes:

ANSWER.PARA: The DSS can and will investigate everything they can about you. The staff there are highly trained and proficient at ferreting out embarrassing things about you, like the fact that you have a . . . job, or that you have $50,000 in the bank.

This is the most accurate point I have found in this book, and our system of detection is better now than when it was originally written. The Department of Social Security now has the fifth biggest public sector computer network in the world, ensuring more foolproof methods of overpayment, detection and calculation. A personal computer network has recently been established to calculate overpayments. It is now being piloted in four States and will shortly be introduced nationwide. We have moved to keep our clients better informed about not only their obligations but also their entitlements. The first batch of plain English advice letters, clearly setting out a client's entitlements and obligations, was sent out in May. State directors report an excellent response from pensioners concerning changed circumstances which will lead, in some cases, to a reduction in entitlement.

The introduction of direct deposits for pensions, family allowances and unemployment benefit last year is estimated to save more than $30m in both fraud and operational costs. Progress reports indicate that 94 per cent of unemployment beneficiaries, 92 per cent of pensioners and 96 per cent of those receiving family allowances now use this method of payment. Only 49 per cent of pensions and family allowances were previously paid by direct deposit.

The computerisation of overpayment recoveries by withholding a portion of a pension or benefit has dramatically improved the rate of overpayment recovery. Last financial year $23.7m was recovered, compared with $10.5m in 1981-82, an increase of more than 100 per cent on the recovery performance of the previous Government. New tough proof of identity procedures are now in place, requiring pension and benefit applicants to produce three proof of identity documents from three different sources. This makes it far more difficult for dishonest applicants to successfully receive a pension or benefit. Furthermore, we have introduced, as part of our overpayments strategy, new computerised selective reviews of those on unemployment, sickness or special benefit. A similar review of pensioners is about to begin. The theory behind that review is that, whereas in the past many of the methods used to seek to detect overpayments were first somewhat comprehensive and then superficial in scope, better targeting of reviews is likely to achieve a higher rate of detection of overpayments and more effective recoveries.

We are reaching the end of the amnesty which the Government announced in February. That amnesty will mean that quite a large number of people who were not guilty of fraud but were in a situation in which they were receiving more than they were entitled to will be able to correct that situation with the Department of Social Security. Arising out of that exercise will be the detection of significant overpayments. I think it is extremely unfortunate, with respect to the issue of overpayments, that there is so much sensationalism of the type that I referred to at the beginning of my answer. It would seem that, every day, people invent figures about the level of overpayments. Very often there is no foundation at all for those figures. Derryn Hinch, in his article on Saturday night, could not even get the figure right. He talked about $300 a month being quoted in the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, whereas the figure quoted in that report was on an annual basis. Furthermore, he suggested that the Committee had made some investigation. Of course, the Committee had made no investigation at all. If one wants to look for the source of that particular amount, one needs to look at the area of the Australian Federal Police and its association, which is seeking to add to Federal Police staffing resources. As we know, the Australian Federal Police has very little interest in social security fraud, which represents a very small area of its concerns. The concerns of the Federal Police are much more on the revenue side of the Budget than on the social security side.

It seems to me that in the discussion of social security overpayments it is important that people preserve some rationality and detachment in terms of the figures that are thrown around. One does not want to have the kind of hysteria which was generated during the period of the Fraser Government and which produced the Greek social security case. The Government will be considering, in the next week or so, the Roma Mitchell report about compensation. Something like six years later we are still dealing with the consequences to the Greek community of the kind of irresponsibility that was generated at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the answer he gave to the first question asked today in which he spoke of the deep-seated problems of the Australian economy. —Has the Minister for Health received representations in relation to the high cost of the drug dilantin, which I understand is used for the treatment of epilepsy? Can the Minister explain the reasons for these high costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. The concern that she shows about the increase in the prices patients have to pay for dilantin is reflected on both sides of the House and is certainly shared by the Government. But that concern should be directed back to the body responsible, that is, the manufacturer Parke Davis, for the quite unwarranted and unjustified increases in the price of dilantin. The prices for dilantin were increased last July on an average of 11 per cent across the board. That increase was granted. Early this year, in March, the manufacturer Parke Davis unilaterally decided to raise the prices by a further 25 per cent. This price increase was rejected by the pricing bureau, which, I point out, includes representatives from the consumer organisations and manufacturers.

ANSWER.PARA: When we were faced with this unilateral price increase from Parke Davis we could have done three things. First of all, we could simply have granted the manufacturer that 25 per cent increase. However, we as a government have a responsibility to maintain a pharmaceutical benefits scheme that produces a subsidised drug scheme without placing high demands on taxpayers themselves. Therefore, simply to grant this 25 per cent unilateral increase in our view would have provided quite unacceptable increases in costs for taxpayers generally. Besides, it would have set a precedent for other drug companies to make the same charges for unique products. That was the first option-simply to agree to the price. The second option was to delist the product which would have meant that the patient would have to pay the full cost, which would have been between $13 and $14. We believed that that option was also unacceptable. Since July last year we have had a third option-a more flexible option-and that is to subsidise the drug up to the agreed price. That would mean that the patient would have to pay that marginal extra cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you negotiate a price increase like you did with every other drug?
—Order!
—Why didn't you negotiate with them.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Barker.

—We regret that this was the option that the Government had to choose but the two other options-that is, accepting this unilateral price increase or simply delisting the product-were not ones the Government would choose. Therefore we adopted the more flexible option. I realise that that means an additional cost of between $1.11 and $1.75 for that extra month's supply. I hope that members of this Parliament and members of the public will direct their concern to the body responsible-that is, Parke Davis-following this quite unjustified unilateral price increase.
—I call the honourable member for Petrie.
—Thank you, Madam Speaker. I have been trying to get your eye for weeks.
—I point out to the honourable member for Petrie that I have been able to see him but others, on the front bench, have been rising.

—Madam Speaker, I was beginning to believe that my diet was too successful. Is the Treasurer aware that, through the introduction of the assets test, thousands of pensioners feel cheated out of their entitlements; through the abandonment of parity pricing, motorists feel cheated on petrol prices; through the abolition of negative gearing, pensioners and low income earners feel cheated because of higher rents; because of the fringe benefits tax, hundreds of thousands of farmers and small businesses feel cheated; because his policies have, in his own words, pushed us towards a banana republic, Australians generally feel cheated; any delay in tax cuts will result in taxpayers feeling cheated; and is he aware--
—Order! Will the honourable member come to the point of his question? I did not realise that he was going to make a speech.
—Thank you, Madam Speaker. It is all question. Is the Treasurer aware that, because of these actions and others, he is commonly being dubbed Mr Cheating?

—If the honourable member, a former Minister of the coalition Government, had had any semblance of understanding about the principles of equity and fairness in the tax and social security systems, we would not have had the appalling mess that this Government inherited. The fact is that receiving a pension regardless of means is not an entitlement. Negative gearing is not pushing up rents; any formerly negatively geared property is grandfathered in; it is still protected by the negative gearing arrangements, as the honourable member overlooked in his discourse. The fringe benefits tax is a taxation of benefits provided to employees outside the taxation system, and the coalition governments have had 30 years to do something about it. But apparently honourable members opposite, in representing their constituents, feel that most of them should carry the burden of other people's tax liabilities while those people can have the benefits of credit cards and motor vehicles and the like. Rather than reflect on me, the question reveals a reflection of the lack of principle, consistency, understanding and decency which pervaded a succession of coalition governments and which is still engrained in the attitude of honourable members opposite that tax breaks should be given to some people but not to others, and that they should be given to those people at the expense of everyone else.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MR ROBERT HOLMES A COURT: CITIZENSHIP

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Did Mr John Valder, the National President of the Liberal Party, in his Westpac video interview in July last year refer to fringe benefits as a disease and indicate a desire to see Labor do the hard tasks and get into trouble as a result? Has the Leader of the Opposition consistently refused to commit a future coalition government to the repeal of the fringe benefits tax? What are the implications of this situation to the Government's fringe benefits tax policy, and what would be the results of a withdrawal of that tax policy?
—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. The honourable member appears to be asking the Treasurer to express an opinion. Under standing order 144--

—Order! The honourable member's question was out of order beforehand because the Minister to whom it was directed is not responsible for what the Liberal Party President has to say. The first part of his question is irrelevant. The last part of the question is the part that the Treasurer will answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the two questions implied in the preface to the question is definitely in the affirmative. To the balance of the question, let me say this: It is true that Mr Valder referred to the whole question of fringe benefits as a disease in his well-publicised interview, and said:

ANSWER.PARA: Well that is why I would like to see them-
that is, the Australian Labor Party-

do the very hard things that they are going to get into trouble about. Because electorally, that is the fact of the matter. They are not easy to do. So I have said many times, you know, let the Labor Party get on implementing the more necessary, but perhaps less popular parts of our policy. And let's hope they get them into place and promptly lose office. And I think that would be a very good scenario, don't you?

It is very interesting that those comments, juxtaposed with the comments of the honourable member for Mackellar and the Leader of the Opposition-the comments that they would not necessarily repeal the fringe benefits tax legislation, but they will use every opportunity to frustrate, attack and score from it as it goes through the House of Representatives and the Senate-indicate perfectly the hypocrisy of the coalition parties. The President of the Liberal Party of Australia can come out and say something as clear as he has about the necessity of changes to the taxation system and the creeping paralysis and disease of fringe benefits, yet the Leader of the Opposition can get up and state at the National Press Club that he would not give a categorical assurance that the fringe benefits tax would be repealed. The Opposition will score from it all the way through.

Today we had the mindless Press statement from the Leader of the Opposition about how the Government was gutless in not applying the existing tax-the tax which existed in all of his years as Treasurer. Talk about shooting yourself in the foot! The fact is that this Government has made it quite clear, because the existing law goes to the value of the fringe benefit to an employee, that every tax that may be implemented under that law would need to be assessed on the basis of the particular value to every separate taxpayer in the community. Hence it has always been the view of the Commissioner of Taxation that those provisions could not be applied, and that is why we need a broad, clear mandate from the Parliament in terms of a specific fringe benefits tax.

The total hypocrisy of the Opposition parties is shown by the fact that they will not support what is an overdue repair to the income tax system, so that the burden of taxation on some people will be reduced and a more fair and equitable burden will be placed on other people who have been avoiding it. It seems to me that the Liberal and National parties, as major parties in this Parliament, should hang their heads in shame at the prospect of opposing the tax. What sort of country do they expect Australia to be if this is the level of leadership and indication of propriety in laws that they are prepared to provide?
I shall read two paragraphs from the leader in the Sydney Morning Herald of last Saturday, because it says volumes about the problem:

Employers say wage earners should accept a real wage cut to help solve Australia's balance of payments problem. But how do Australia's managers behave when they are asked to make a small sacrifice? They rant about how the fringe benefits tax will stifle enterprise, they call on each other to break the law, and they babble about Boston Tea Parties. Edifying stuff: wage earners must make a sacrifice, but not us. It really is no wonder wage earners treat arguments for wage restraint as trickery by chiselling employers.

Just ask yourself what, exactly, Australia's managers are being asked to give up? Well, first, they are being asked to pay their tax. Of course, there will be compensations: the top marginal tax rate will drop from 60 per cent to 49 per cent (people on high incomes who have been paying their tax will get a very big tax cut); the double taxation of company dividends will be abolished, at a cost to the taxpayer of about $250 million a year. Bob Ansett and Ian McLachlan and their supporters want all the benefits, they just want to shirk the cost.

`Well said', I say to the leader writer of the Sydney Morning Herald. Many other employers, of course, are prepared to do the right thing and pay their fair share of the burden. I would not want to think that those comments go to every employer; obviously, they do not. But it is an indication of people who wish to have an exalted position in the eyes of this community-and that goes for McLachlan and Ansett-but who, whenever they are asked by the public to observe the law in respect of what has been a national debate about fringe benefits, urge people to break the law. Considering the lack of principle on the part of the Opposition in opposing this measure and looking at attitudes of the kind referred to in the Sydney Morning Herald, is it any wonder that ordinary Australians should start to wonder about the quality of the leadership and the sense of decency pervading in all sections of the community, including political parties, about Australia's future? They may well ponder the behaviour of the coalition parties in this place and their supporters in private business who want all the pluses but none of the negatives.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The false argument of the Government that income tax cuts are dependent on the passage of the fringe benefits tax legislation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the numbers of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Opposition wishes to take up the argument that has been put about by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that unless the notorious fringe benefits tax is passed by both Houses of Parliament there will be either no tax cuts or a serious delay in those cuts. I wish to expose today quite clearly the fallacy in the argument that there is necessarily any link whatsoever between the promise made solemnly by the Treasurer in his statement of 19 September last year and the passage of the notorious fringe benefits tax through this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point that we notice is that there is no equality of argument in the sums involved. The tax cuts promised on 19 September amount to $2 billion-$2,000m-beginning on 1 September this year. This House wants to make it quite clear that it still expects the $2,000m in tax cuts to be effective from 1 September. If those cuts do not come then, it will be another clear breach of promise by this breach of promise Treasurer. A total of $2,000m is involved in the tax cuts, but how much exactly is involved in the Treasurer's estimates of the fringe benefits tax in the first year? The answer is exactly $330m. So, first of all, the Treasurer is saying that $2,000m worth of tax cuts is potentially in jeopardy because a fringe benefits tax, based on his estimates to be worth $330m, will not be passed by the Senate. That does not add up. Only one dollar in six of the proposed tax cuts for next financial year would come from the fringe benefits tax, even if that tax netted what the Treasurer said.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—Only one dollar in six.
—Where is the Treasurer?

—The question has been rightly asked: Where is the Treasurer? He has been listed to speak in this debate. Honourable members are waiting once again for the Treasurer to come into this House. Here he is; here he comes sauntering in again, treating the House, as usual, with arrogance and contempt. But at least he is here.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I wish to make about the inequality of the argument is that in the first full year-in 1987-88-the Treasurer has promised tax cuts worth $4,500m. How much of that amount will come from the fringe benefits tax? The Treasurer estimates that only $540m will come from that tax. So, in the second year, which is the first full year, on the Treasurer's estimates-and I assume that he is right-only one dollar in eight of the promised tax cuts will come out of the fringe benefits tax receipts. Clearly the Treasurer's arguments to the Australian public that the tax cuts are in jeopardy because of threats to the fringe benefits tax are a total nonsense. In the first year only one dollar in six will come from the fringe benefits tax and in the second year only one dollar in eight will come from that source. Therefore, it is a total nonsense to suggest that if the Senate-as it should do-cuts off this miserable, rotten tax we will lose our tax cuts.

Another point about these tax cuts that we are promised is that basically they are not real tax cuts at all. If one examines the figures one finds that the tax cuts are merely a correction for fiscal drag. What is fiscal drag? Let us take this term and explain exactly what it means because every taxpayer recognises the effects of it. It means that as inflation goes up-and under this Government inflation is currently 9.2 per cent or three times that of our trading partners, three times that of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-and as wages rise, people move into higher tax brackets. Consequently, without altering a tittle of the taxation law, this Treasurer can drag in, as he has done over the past three years, a great deal more tax. Without his doing a thing, more and more tax is taken from individuals and companies throughout the land because of fiscal drag.

I must say that the unions are awake to this. They are demanding that this Treasurer meet the tax cuts on the promised date because they know as well as everyone else around the country that if those tax cuts do not come in as promised, people will be denied a relief from the effects of inflation. Even if the tax cuts come in on time, 50 per cent of all taxpayers will still be paying a top rate of 40c or more in the dollar. That is even with the tax cuts. Indeed, even with the tax cuts, the average weekly earnings of an average taxpayer will be taxed at a higher rate. The average rate of tax he pays currently is 22.73 per cent and, even after the promised tax cuts, the rate will increase to 24.48 per cent. In other words, even with the promised tax cuts, the average weekly earnings taxpayer will be paying a higher average rate of tax by the time the full package comes in, if it comes in. Therefore, the Treasurer must meet this tax commitment just to try to stop people from going backwards. They will go backwards anyway with the package, but they will go backwards even further if he does not meet his commitments. Therefore, it is essential for the Treasurer to introduce his tax cuts, not just to counteract the inflation effects, but also because his union pals will cut up rough if he does not honour the deal he has done with them under accord mark 2. Then he will be in major trouble.

The Treasurer asks where the money will come from. First of all, in the first year five-sixths of it will not be dependent on the fringe benefits tax. In the second year seven-eighths of it will not be dependent on the fringe benefits tax. If the Treasurer needs $330m in the first year, why does he not cut spending by that amount in addition to what he has already planned? This is the big spending Treasurer. Over the past 12 months he has gone around trying to kid people that he has been a careful spender. He has said that this Government has done more than any other government-and he said this the other day, which was quite astonishing-to cut back on government expenditure. We all know, because we have looked at the books which were actually supplied by him and his Treasury, that his Government has spent taxpayers' funds at more than twice the rate of the Fraser Government, averaging its seven years of office. In the seven Fraser years the average increase in spending after inflation was 2.1 per cent. Under this Treasurer it has been an average over the three years of 5.5 per cent.

Why does the Treasurer come round to us and ask us where we would find the money? He has already spent it. He spent up big in years one, two and three of his administration and now he comes screaming to us and asking us where we would find the money. Well, we say this: Five-sixths of the money in year one is not dependent upon fringe benefits tax, seven-eighths of the money in year two is not dependent on fringe benefits tax and the rest of the money-$330m in the first year and $500m in the second year-he must get from cutting government spending. If he does that he will have the additional benefit that he will be doing something about his disastrous banana republic problem of the balance of payments.

As a first step, the most important thing the Treasurer can do to start reducing the deficit and the current account and to start reducing this terrible balance of payments problem is to cut government spending, and to cut it deep. If he does that, he will have the money to pay for what he will lose on this lousy fringe benefits tax. If he does not drop the fringe benefits tax, he is going to be in more trouble than any Treasurer in the history of this country.

Will the tax actually raise what the Treasurer says it will raise? This depends on whether one believes him, particularly in relation to the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles, or whether one believes Senator Button, Mr John Bannon, the Premier of South Australia, or the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia, because all those people have broadly the same view on the effects of the fringe benefits tax on the motor industry. On my calculations based on their figures, if this tax is imposed the Government would lose about $300m in taxes and revenue and this industry would be destroyed. That is based on the figure of his colleague Senator Button, who even over the weekend repeated the fact that he totally disagrees with the imposition of this tax on the motor industry. Senator Button disagrees with him publicly. Once again we have two senior Ministers in conflict over this matter, yet the Treasurer doggedly sticks to this tombstone despite the fact that it is ruining the motor industry and it is going to have a serious effect on other industries.

The other point, of course, that the Treasurer makes is that he is an extremely moral person, that he is concerned about the morality of taxation, that by comparison with the previous Government he is a model of rectitude and that it is quite immoral to allow certain existing things to go on without taking some action. People are starting to have their own views about the particular remedy that he is proposing. This little purple booklet on the fringe benefits tax has now gone out to all employers. They are all reading it and day by day they are seeing the quality of the Treasurer's solution to this supposed problem of immorality.

Where is the morality in this? This morning I had drawn to my attention a particular case put forward by the Australian Hotels Association. The Treasurer will rubbish this Association, I may as well warn it. If people have the effrontery to put up a well argued case, the Treasurer will say that they are one of these narrow vested interests, that they cannot be listened to and so on. But let the Treasurer deny what the Australian Hotels Association says in its case. Let him deny that clause 27 of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 makes it clear that the fact that an employee, in residential accommodation provided by the employer, provides some sort of service such as being on call to make sure that burglars do not get into the pub is not taken into account in the levying of the tax. Clause 27 says that it does not matter if, in the course of occupying that accommodation, one has other duties such as being sure one is there all the time to make sure that the pub is not burgled. It gives this particular case-it is a real case-where an employee licensee in an inner city hotel in Melbourne, who I might say in Victoria is required to be there by law, runs an extended trading licence to 3 a.m. and has to undertake a stocktake at the close of trading every night. He lives on the premises in a unit which is not particularly attractive but which is valued at $180 per week by the Taxation Office because of its prime location. It is in an area where much more luxurious units rent for over $250 per week. The taxable value of this employee licensee who stays on the premises all the time and who makes sure that burglars do not come in and who has to do a stocktake after 3 a.m. is $135 per week. That is the value, under the legislation, for the fringe benefit.

Case two is a middle management merchant bank executive. Of course, the Treasurer does not like merchant bank executives. He hates them. They are the people who allegedly put down the value of the dollar by trading. Honourable members will recall what he said about them. He does not like these people. Nonetheless, under this arrangement he has given them a benefit which he has not given to the other people. A middle management merchant bank executive who lives in a quality unit in the suburbs to which he can return to each evening to relax has the rent of $135 a week paid for by his employer as the unit is part of the employee's remuneration package. Its taxable value of $135 is exactly the same as that for the fellow in the downtown pub who has to do the stocktake and look after the premises late at night. Where is the morality in that? Is that a way of getting at the problem of equity in taxation? Is that a way of getting at benefits which ought to be taxed? I think that is hardly a solution.

When one looks at a farmer who provides lodging, perhaps a sheep or two, firewood from dead trees, the use of a farm vehicle to drive the kids to the school bus and all these sorts of things hidden under the fringe benefits tax, where is the morality? Are we really impressed by that? What is the morality in putting a fringe benefit on a charity, on a religious body or on a non-profit organisation for a few miserable uses of a car or another vehicle by an employee whose main job is to look after the people that that charity is supposed to look after during the day? On the books already is legislation that this Treasurer could have used to deal with this question of equity and morality. Legislation is already on the books which he could have used but which he has failed to use.

Where is the morality in profligate spending, after all? Where is the morality in increasing spending by an average of 5.5 per cent in real terms over three years and then squeezing farmers and charities? Where is the morality in that? Just where is it? Where is the morality in pretending to people that if they do not pass the fringe benefits tax they cannot get tax cuts, where the fringe benefit money is only one-sixth or one-eighth of the total sum the Treasurer is talking about? If he wants to have a debate about morality, we will have it any day at all. We will examine it case by case and the Australian people will examine it case by case as they turn over every page of this 56 pages of fringe benefits tax nonsense. He will live with this and he will regret it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is stunned by the charge of immorality in the tax system, and well it might be, because for years it presided over the degradation of the Australian taxation system. The Opposition watched it fall to pieces. It watched the criminal paper evasion schemes proliferate. It did nothing about them until it was a national scandal. The tax losses revealed by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the McCabe-Lafranchi report put the losses in relation to the size of our tax system way ahead of every other country in the world. It was on a scale of five or six times tax avoidance in the United States of America in the years of the Howard Administration. The fact is that the coalition Government was just totally unprepared to do anything about the degradation of the tax system, even the blatant criminal paper evasion schemes, much less the rutted-in avoidance schemes and avoidance practices, of which fringe benefits is one. It left this Government with a Taxation Office with its morale shot to pieces as the Taxation Office had written to the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, for years urging action but was rebuffed. Its staff and resources diminished enormously over the years. When one gets up and reminds the Opposition of its disgraceful stewardship of the tax system, honourable members opposite spring up trying to bring up some obscure circumstance about the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Even in the presentation we have just heard about the rent paid by the hotelier on the accommodation in the hotel for the person doing the stocktake, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) omitted to say that that hotelier would have the double tax on dividends removed by the same package-it is a package of measures, one impacting upon the other-that the tax which would be paid, which is now paid at the company rate and then paid on a personal basis on the distributed earnings of the company, will now be abolished and will be paid only once. That is a massive advantage for companies. If, in the case mentioned, the hotel is privately owned and is not incorporated, there will be a reduction in the marginal rate from 60 per cent to 49 per cent. That is not mentioned in the one-sided, biased recital of the statistics and argument just given by the honourable member for Mackellar. He understands that this is a package-on the one side to make the system fair, clean and decent and on the other to give all the revenue, every penny, back in reduced marginal rates of tax; it also includes the eradication of the double tax on dividends in companies and the development of a full imputation system.

The Opposition made no mention of the package approach. We have had just a selective indignation about the way in which the scheme operates. More than any other of these matters of public importance in recent days, this one illustrates the woolly-headed, Magic Pudding thinking of the coalition-that there is money to be plucked from anywhere. In fact the Leader of the Opposition, in a Press statement issued yesterday, said:
Any revenue shortfall from defeat of the fringe benefits tax could easily be made up by the Government slashing its own spending by another $300 to $400m in 1986-87.

That is it, it is so easy; we just take a decision to cut off another $300m or $400m. The Opposition has to be joking. This comes from a Party which now has $5 billion of outlays and tax expenditure commitments since the last election and keeps piling them up. It comes from a Leader of the Opposition who, as Treasurer, was unable to cut more than $250m in the celebrated razor gang exercise of his years as Treasurer. The fact is that this Government has cut over $3.5 billion out of expenditures and outlays in three Budgets and will go on into this fourth Budget. To say `There is $400m, do not worry about it, just add it to the deficit' is the kind of nonsense which every serious person watching the economy in this country regards as a total sham and in no way an answer or solution to the problem.

The reality is that the Government has never said that the income tax cuts are solely dependent on the introduction of the fringe benefits tax. So the central premise of the matter of public importance is wrong in the first place. Obviously the revenue raised by the fringe benefits tax makes an important contribution to income tax cuts-it is all money. But we have never said that the income tax cuts are solely dependent on the introduction of the fringe benefits tax. At least I welcome this recognition by the Opposition of the fact that the tax measures are part of an overall package involving impacts upon the Budget, which the Opposition has not recognised up until this time. The fringe benefits tax exists and stands in its own right because it is designed to make the tax system fairer, to flush out the rorts and ramps that have flourished under the previous Government, and to get to a position where all taxpayers will feel that the system is fairer and that some taxpayers, ordinary taxpayers, are not carrying a burden which they know they are shouldering on behalf of somebody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us have an election on it.

—The last thing the honourable member would ever want an election on is tax decency. In terms of tax decency the coalition would not have a leg to stand on. It would not last an hour in the first day of the first week. Whether it was credit cards for free meals in restaurants or private use of vehicles written off at 100 per cent business use, it meant that the average taxpayer had to carry the burden of those costs by higher levels of taxation, while they have not enjoyed these fringe benefits. That is why Mr Valder, the Federal President of the Liberal Party, agrees with the Government that the existence of fringe benefits is a disease. In the face of these steep marginal rates of tax which the coalition Government gave Australia, the propensity to minimise tax and use fringe benefits avenues has increased. All the more reason why now in reducing the marginal rates of tax there is a case for dealing with these fringe benefits. We have dealt with them in the most fair-minded and balanced way a government could ever hope to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The difference between the Government and the coalition is that this Government has had the guts and decency to do something about the problem, instead of sweeping it under the carpet, knowing that one body of Australians pay their fair share of tax and the others bludge on them. The Opposition now knows that this Government is not prepared to sweep it under the carpet, and that we have had the decency and moral strength to do something about it, despite the fact that the Opposition is baying at our heels raising opportunist propositions like this in the Parliament.

Yet Opposition members want respect. They strut around the corridors as if people should respect them as parliamentarians, with a position in politics and public life. Their position is immoral, as this debate reveals. They are not entitled to any corporate respectability as a Party holding these views. That is why they have been held in contempt by the Government and by the country as a whole. We are not about to cave in to some opportunist claim by the Opposition that we should drop the fringe benefits tax proposal, that it is some unreasonable impost. We hear nothing from the Opposition about a full imputation system, the eradication of the double tax on dividends and a reduction in the rates of marginal tax. The Opposition opposes all the revenue raising measures but supports the tax reduction. What a joke!

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about fiscal drag.
—Order! The honourable member for Richmond will cease interjecting.

—He is more to be pitied than despised, Mr Deputy Speaker: Do not worry about him. The fact is Opposition members oppose all the measures that would raise the revenue to reduce the tax. One would think they would have enough sense to say: `We never did it and we know that we should have. At least the Government has come along and has taken a punch on the chin on this or that, but this ought to be done. At least let us support it and then we will not be pressed to take it away when we are in office. Even if we support it, the Government will bear the burden of it, if there is any burden to be borne'. Opposition members are so aware of their own self-interest and not cognisant of any consideration of decent public policy that they are not even sensible enough to support that line.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Leader of the Opposition was asked whether he would repeal these measures he replied: `Well, I am not going to lock a future government into some rigid formula'. Then he gives the National Press Club the line of argument that he will not say that he will repeal the fringe benefits tax, but just that he will oppose it everywhere. He will oppose it in the House of Representatives; he will oppose it in the Senate; he will attack it on radio programs. When he is pressed to answer the question `If it is that objectionable, Mr Howard, will you repeal it?' he says: `Oh, no, we will not repeal it; we cannot lock ourselves into something like this'. Really! Then the honourable member for Mackellar comes along with another pedestrian performance rattling out half truths, distortions, exaggerations, mixed up views, fiscal lunacy-the whole lot.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a long way off your best.

—I do not have to rise to any occasion here; do not make under any mistake about that. I could beat this argument staying in bed. I would not even have to come here to roll this little case. It is a complete sham. The other case Opposition members put is that the Government has the power under the existing law. Mr Howard believes that the Government is gutless in not exercising existing law. Well, why did not Mr Howard exercise it in 1983, 1982, 1981, 1980, 1979 and 1978? Was he gutless for five years? Opposition members are nodding approval, so he was.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is well aware that section 26 of the Income Tax Assessment Act provides that the value to the taxpayer of all allowances, compensations and benefits given in respect of employment, whether in money, goods or services, is assessable income. The problems with the administration of the section are long standing, which the Opposition well understands. They have become rutted into the system and are now virtually impossible to solve without firm legislative measures. The Opposition knows that although those provisions have been there, they are dormant and useless and have to be addressed directly by legislative change. The main problem in the existing legislation is that as a tax on employees there are very substantial compliance problems and valuation problems, more particularly because the section relates to the value to the employee, and a highly subjective case by case assessment becomes necessary.

One cannot ask the Commissioner to look behind the value, or what is regarded as the value to the employee, in respect of seven million taxpayers. It is not viable. This is largely unworkable because subjectivity will lead to a flood of objections and appeals which involve massive bureaucratic costs to resolve. That is why something legislative had to be done. The cost to revenue of tax evasion in this area was estimated in the draft White Paper at $700m. The fringe benefits tax will recoup most, though not all, of this loss. The decision to impose the fringe benefits tax on employers has clear advantages as it will introduce objective rather than subjective tax rules, which the Opposition well understands. It is administratively cheaper because the total number of taxpayers is less. Group certificates and monthly pay as you earn arrangements, which would have involved massive paperwork burdens on business, are avoided, and the chaotic results of the sorts of measures tried by the Opposition in 1980 in taxing the Queensland coal miners on a discriminatory basis are avoided. The fact is that members of the Opposition make this cheap point, never having been prepared to administer these provisions themselves as a government, knowing that it was incapable of such administration. It now says that this Government ought to fall back to those provisions, when it knows that there is a clear legislative need for clear rules to be brought in to deal with the problem of fringe benefits.

All we have is the usual obfuscation, double standards and lack of any shred of moral position in the state of the Liberal and National parties in this Parliament in respect of fringe benefits. The coalition opposes most of the changes to the tax system to make it cleaner and better. It wants reductions in marginal rates. It wants the full imputation system which this Government will give business-the greatest single reform to the corporate taxation system since its inception-which it was asked to give by a succession of business communities in 20 or 30 years and refused. It mentions nothing about that. It will have all the goodies but none of the baddies, and the baddies are okay anyway. That is the Opposition's attitude. If that is its attitude, let public opinion be a judge of the veracity of its views and opinions and the moral standpoint it takes. We on this side of the House take the view that those people who have been paying more than their fair share, the families with children on $18,000 or $20,000 a year, trying to battle along, pay mortgages and run a second hand vehicle and all the rest, should not be loaded up with tax while the people the Opposition represents escape through the tax net by having their tax liabilities diminished. The Opposition will get no change from me or from the Government. We think its position is groundless, immoral and opportunist. It could do the decent thing and support these measures, but while it persists in its current frame of mind it will get no change or support for its position from us.

—Now he has walked out.

—Of course, he has just walked out. The Treasurer has suggested that if the Opposition combines with the Australian Democrats in the Senate to block this iniquitous, unfair, expensive and excessive tax on fringe benefits, income tax cuts for Australians will be in jeopardy. SPEECH.PARA: What the Treasurer has not said is that the income tax cuts themselves are illusory. They are being supplied by his old mate fiscal drag, because this Treasurer has refused to do anything to reduce the impact of inflation on income tax scales. In fact, it is as a result of his policies that we will have a greater impact from fiscal drag than perhaps we have seen for many years. This Treasurer has given the Australian people an inflation rate of 9.4 per cent. That means that every year all Australian workers will be moving into higher and higher income tax brackets. It means that by the time these tax cuts come into effect the average Australian worker will be paying more tax than he is at present. This man has the nerve to come in here and talk about morality, about consistency, but refused to talk about the numbers behind his tax policies. He knows that he is in trouble, he knows that he cannot keep the promises, and he knows that he has to run for cover. He also knows that he is in trouble with the factional politics of the Australian Labor Party.

Frankly, the Expenditure Review Committee he was relying on to cut back expenditure is just not working. A brawl is going on inside the Labor Party amongst the magnificent seven. We have a member of the magnificent seven sitting at the table, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). To the people who want to keep spending money the Treasurer says: `Please do not spend any more money because I cannot raise it fast enough'. The Treasurer says this notwithstanding the fact that he is running a record high tax revenue Budget, notwithstanding the fact that he has government receipts at record high levels. He knows that he is in trouble because there is no way he can keep within the guidelines of that fundamental tenet laid down by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the trilogy.

The trilogy has gone out the window. It is absolutely nonsense. Even in the first year the Government could not comply with the parameters of that trilogy. As everybody knows, the trilogy committed this Government to not increasing tax receipts, outlays or the Budget deficit as a proportion of the gross domestic product above the 1984-85 levels, a year in which tax receipts were at an all time record level. This year tax receipts will be ahead of the 1984-85 level. They will be, on current estimates, $1,000m over the Budget estimate. If this Treasurer goes ahead with the line he is trotting out that if the fringe benefits tax is stopped he will have to postpone income tax cuts, and if he postpones them until about December this year it will add about another $600m to government revenue. So again, this Government will break the trilogy.

No one in this chamber, no one in the gallery, and no one listening, should be at all surprised that the Government will break another promise because this Government probably has broken more promises than the Treasurer has had hot breakfasts. One only has to go back to see what the Prime Minister said in his 1983 policy speech to understand how valueless this Government's words are. The Prime Minister, then the Leader of the Opposition, in 1983 said: `I am not, and the Labor Party is not, in the business of making promises that can't be kept'. It has not kept a promise since that date. It has not kept the promise about the capital gains tax. We have a capital gains tax here; we are about to debate that legislation. It has not honoured the promise to increase pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. What about fuel prices? The present Prime Minister said in 1983: `As soon as I am elected, fuel prices will drop 3c'. They did not drop 3c, they just kept going up and up. Even when the world price of oil did fall because of economic circumstances, what happened to the poor Australian motorists? They still got fiddled. This Government pulled the greatest swiftie of all time. The ultimate bowser bandit, the Treasurer, who is not even in the chamber any more, took them for a ride. The Australian people know it, and they know that he is about to take them for a ride again on tax revenues. There is no way this Government will survive the impact of its iniquitous fringe benefits tax.

What it has not done is examine the impact this tax will have on the Australian economy. We already have a situation where business in Australia, for the first time in our history, is talking about a revolt, about disobeying laws passed by this Parliament. Can anyone blame them? When we look at what this Government's tax will do we see that it will affect some 60 per cent of the Australian work force. About three million Australians receive fringe benefits, and this Government proposes to tax them in the hands of the employer. I do not believe that this Government has done any work to ascertain exactly what this tax will cost the Australian farm sector. The Livestock and Grain Producers Association has estimated that the tax will cost the farm sector $152m. It is appropriate that the Minister for Primary Industry is at the table because, quite frankly, I do not think he is doing his job very well. In circumstances where the average farm income is $4,000 or a bit less he will allow the Treasurer to impose a fringe benefits tax on things such as firewood from dead trees, or using a station vehicle to take the kids to the farm gate so they can catch the school bus. He will allow that tax to be imposed and it will cost the average Australian farmer about $1,000 in a year when the average farm income is just less than $4,000. I wonder whether the Treasurer has been told by the Minister for Primary Industry that, unlike a lot of other businesses, farmers are not in a position to pass on this extra cost, and that they will have to wear it. It is going to reduce their income, profitability and viability and will put more people off the land. The Minister is oblivious to the impact of these policies. He was supposed to have set up a section within the Department of Primary Industry to look at the impact of government policies on the farm sector. I will tell you what; it must be sitting there looking at its navel because it certainly has not said anything about the impact of the fringe benefits tax on the farm sector.

I just cannot understand this Government. What it is really seeking to do is continually to increase tax revenue rather than address the real problems of Australia at present. There is an overwhelming need, accepted by everybody in Australia, except the people who occupy the benches opposite, to reduce government expenditure. In fact, this need is even accepted by some members of the Government. Only last week the Minister for Finance spoke about the need to control the social security system. The good senator-a man of some intelligence and some capacity to analyse figures, including the figures put up by his ministerial colleagues-has said that the amount of cheating going on under the Labor Administration in regard to the unemployment benefit has increased. In fact, he mentioned the figure of $100m. Quite frankly, if the Government did something about cheating in regard to the unemployment benefit and tightened up the social security system it would have $100m of the money it needs or proposes to raise through the fringe benefits tax. Of course, Senator Walsh went on to talk about supporting parents' benefits. Of course he addressed the problem of the non-collection of maintenance. He addressed the fact that we are currently spending $1.2 billion on the supporting parent's benefit, which spending is increasing at the rate of 10 per cent a year. Seventy per cent of maintenance orders are not complied with. What has this Government done in three years to do anything about that? Absolutely nothing. No wonder the Government has to contrive new taxes to impose on Australian business, which is having the greatest difficulty in the history of this nation in competing internationally.

Everybody in this country, with the exception of the Treasurer, recognises the problems. Only last Saturday an article in the Melbourne Herald talked about this Government's records. The Government likes to talk about its records but only selectively. Let us talk about some of the other records of this Government. The writer of the column `Martin's Place' in the Melbourne Herald states:
. . . The Government's policy of record interest rates, a record relative inflation rate--

—Better than yours.

—It is not a good one. The honourable member for Mackellar interjected: `Better than yours'. What about the Budget deficit the former Government left us with? The Liberal-National Party Government presided over a huge blow-out in the deficit in its last year of office. What record do honourable members opposite have in cutting deficits?
