SPEECH.PARA: What areas is the Opposition looking at? Is it addressing areas such as the family allowance? I suppose the Opposition will once again come up with the old perennial proposal of cutting back the Public Service. The Opposition is always good for that one-it comes up in the lead-up to every Budget by the Opposition. This is the sort of line that the Opposition puts forward. On the one hand it says: `Okay, we will go ahead with this proposal to cut back the marginal tax rates and we will get the money by cutting government spending'. However, its record of doing that is absolutely appalling. I do not think anyone in the Australian community would be prepared to accept that simplistic alternative to the view that we have put that we must have a proper reform of the taxation system.

When we talk about morality in tax we have to look at the area of fringe benefits. We have to do so in isolation from how much revenue we will get from this type of taxation and where that revenue will go. We have to look at the morality of whether a fringe benefits tax should be part of the Australian taxation system. It is my view, and the view of this Government, that such a tax should be an integral part of a fair and equitable taxation system for this country.

It is also interesting to note that tax reform inquiries conducted in other countries have all come to the unanimous view that there must be a fringe benefits tax. This matter was addressed recently by Mr John Kay, a noted British tax economist, who put this whole debate into international perspective. He compared reports on tax reform in the United States of America, Canada, the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Ireland and Australia and found the reports to be strikingly similar in the broad thrust of their recommendations. He illustrated this by focusing on several main areas, including choice of tax base, treatment of fringe benefits and rate structures. I will not go into all the details but, in relation to fringe benefits, Kay observed:
. . . there is no subject on which there is such clear agreement.

I repeat: Speaking about all the inquiries that were conducted all over the Western world into the sorts of tax reform proposals that should be introduced, Kay said that there was no other subject on which there was such clear agreement. So even if we take out of this whole debate the question of how much revenue one is going to get from the fringe benefits tax and how that money is to be spent, we still have to address the basic question of tax morality, of whether we should have a fringe benefits tax. Although the Opposition says no to that, it does not quite say no. It says that we should not have this sort of legislation. However, we are not given any clear answer when we ask the basic question whether it would abolish the tax if it ever got into government. We have not heard an outright cry of `yes, we will'. I notice that the honourable member for Mackellar, when interviewed last week on a local Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program, did not make any categorical statement that he would make sure that this tax was abolished. We have heard what Valder said about it. I understand that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) would not give a categorical assurance when he was asked at a Press conference whether he would abolish this tax.

So where are we left? On the one hand the Opposition says: `Okay, we do not support this legislation. However, we are not prepared to say that we would make sure that this tax is abolished'. On the other hand, it is saying: `Do not worry about the revenue you could gain from that because you can just reduce government spending'. However, we have to remember that the Government has made a commitment that the revenue gained from this tax shall be returned to the taxpayers of Australia. That is an integral part of the tax cuts.

We are talking about the collection of in the vicinity of half a billion dollars in 1986-87 and about the same amount in 1987-88 as a result of the fringe benefits tax legislation. That is a lot of money. A lot of cuts would have to be made if one were to get that same amount of money in other ways. That money will go back into the pocket of the honest Australian taxpayer. This legislation will enable a reduction to be made in the amount of tax all wage and salary earners pay. Even in the 60c category there will be a cut of 11c. In the 48c category there will be a cut of 8c and in the 46c category a cut of 6c. That money is going directly towards funding these tax cuts.

The Opposition also raised the matter of tax morality. The morality that it has and that it is espousing in this Parliament is based on the adage `Make me pure but not yet-make me pure because the Opposition believes that we must change marginal tax rates but let us not go into the details of how we do it'. The Opposition does not want to make any major sacrifices. It does not support the fringe benefits tax. The Opposition says that the only way to get the revenue to finance these tax cuts is by cutting government spending. What the Opposition is doing by advocating that the Senate reject the fringe benefits tax is abandoning the principle of tax reform. If one starts down that slippery slope, where does one stop? What sort of fringe benefits tax does the Opposition believe we should have in this country? If it does not believe in a fringe benefits tax on cars, what about a fringe benefits tax on education or on restaurants? Where does the Opposition stop? Our tax base has been so dramatically eroded by fringe benefits and how they work in practice that this Government had to address the problems of tax reform and the erosion of the tax base.

If the fringe benefits tax legislation is rejected in the Senate it will be a victory for the power of lobbying over the principle and rationale of tax reform. If this Government loses this opportunity to bring about a fair and equitable tax system it will lose the opportunity for a whole generation. We may never have that opportunity again. It is a disgrace that the Opposition does not present any real alternative to the tax proposals we have brought forward and that it is not looking seriously at ways to stop the erosion of the tax base which has occurred in this country and which it presided over.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 245th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled `The Selection and Development of Senior Managers in the Commonwealth Public Service-Response to report 202, which contains the Department of Finance minute on the Committee's 202nd report.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Committee's 202nd report on the selection and development of senior managers in the Commonwealth Public Service was tabled in Parliament on 28 October 1982. The objectives of that inquiry were to foster improved selection and development methods for senior public servants and to enhance the productivity and performance of the departments and agencies of the Commonwealth Public Service by improving the standard of senior management. This report-the 245th from the Committee-sets out the response to the Committee's findings in report 202 and its comments on that response. The most significant result from the Committee's point of view was that in December 1983 the Government issued a policy paper entitled `Reforming the Australian Public Service'. The proposed reforms addressed the increasing complexity of government operations and also the need for an increase in managerial ability and accountability. The reforms also reflect the perceived requirement for increased responsiveness by senior public servants to ministerial requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the issues and recommendations raised in the 202nd report were addressed in that policy paper and implemented by several pieces of legislation, the most significant of which was the Public Service Reform Act 1985. The Public Service Reform Act, among other things, provides for the appointment of secretaries for fixed periods, the establishment of the Senior Executive Service, Senior Executive Service vacancies to be open to applicants from outside the Australian Public Service, greater mobility within the Senior Executive Service, the regular appraisal of work performance and staff development needs, the establishment of a temporary assignment pool, no appeals against promotions to the Senior Executive Service, and the provision of improved staff development opportunities on the basis of assessments of the needs of individual officers. A number of other personnel policy initiatives have also been addressed, specifically the development of equal employment opportunity and industrial democracy initiatives, the establishment of permanent part time employment through the Australian Public Service and more departmental emphasis and resources to be devoted to the development of internal management development programs and management training for senior staff.

Although the Committee was satisfied with the overall response to the 202nd report, it felt that a number of the recommendations were not responded to adequately and sought further details from the Public Service Board. The Committee recommended that a committee of senior officials be established to identify Second Division and Third Division officers who had exceptional potential on the basis of nominations by departments and suggested assignments to enhance their development. The Public Service Board, while accepting the principle of the recommendation, has varied the mechanism by which that objective could be achieved. The Committee sees merit in this varied mechanism and the response indicates the Board's view that the intent of the recommendation will be achieved. Nonetheless, the Committee is disappointed that no special arrangements have yet been put in place to identify officers who have exceptional potential for promotion.

The Committee notes that a pilot staff appraisal program is to be introduced into six departments by the Public Service Board. This scheme will seek to identify suitable appraisal criteria. It may be that when this is fully developed the proposed scheme could go a long way towards identifying potential promotees. The Committee recommended the establishment of a task force to investigate selection criteria for a written senior staff appraisal scheme and to report within 12 months to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. However, that task force has not been established and no report has gone to the appropriate Minister. The development and implementation of the staff appraisal scheme is being undertaken by the Senior Executive Staffing Unit, which is also yet to report in any form to the Parliament or to the Minister. The Committee therefore regards the report as necessary and requires a progress report from the Public Service Board giving an indication of when completion and implementation of the staff appraisal scheme will take place. The report was a milestone in the Committee's bipartisan approach to the achievement of the goals of economy, efficiency and effectiveness in public administration. I recommend this report to honourable members and honourable senators.

If one reads the report one will find that, in paragraphs 1.9 and 1.10 on page 2, two of those matters are dealt with. In this report the Committee is somewhat scathing in its criticism of the Public Service Board for the way in which this matter has been dealt with. It ought to be understood that the Committee's commendation of the work that has been achieved has to be measured against the extent to which recommendations of the Committee were not followed up or implemented and the extent to which the Public Service Board has failed to provide information or, more to the point, to convince the Committee that its original judgment was wrong. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As the previous Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts responsible for the tabling of the 202nd report on `The Selection and Development of Senior Managers in the Commonwealth Public Service', naturally I am very interested to see the response which has just been tabled by my colleague the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly). The 245th report contains the responses of the Public Service Board and departments to the recommendations made by the Committee. I commend the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). I am delighted to see that with my departure from the Public Accounts Committee my position was so ably filled by him. The honourable member for Canberra, who was very closely involved with me in the development of the recommendations in the 202nd report, has continued her very close association with Australian Public Service reform. I compliment her for it.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Canberra drew attention to a number of very important matters in the response of the departments to the report. In particular she noted that, while the recommendations by the Committee were, generally speaking, accepted by the Hawke Government and included in its initial White Paper entitled `Reforming the Australian Public Service', a statement of the Government's intentions made in 1983, nevertheless a range of other reforms recommended by the Public Accounts Committee have not to date seen the light of day. More importantly, some have not been the subject of worthwhile investigation by the Public Service Board or relevant departments. I join the honourable member for Dundas in stating my concern. This is not a new phenomenon; it apparently permeates all governments: Recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee, like those of most other committees of the Parliament, can be simply put aside for another day.

The responsibilities of the Government in relation to the efficiency and effectiveness of its public servants and, in particular, in relation to the success or otherwise of the machinery of government in administering policies is of the greatest importance to all of us. For too long there has been a tendency for members of parliament, in particular, to imagine that they can dream great dreams which by some extraordinary osmosis will be turned into reality. The fact is that the reality and effectiveness of any policy depend on not only the logic but also the basis upon which the policy was determined in the first place. Equally important is the administrative machinery in place to ensure that the policy can be implemented in the most cost-effective manner possible. It is in that area in particular that there has been a tendency for members of parliament, perhaps on all sides, to fall somewhat short of the ideal, which is to understand the principles of public administration and be able to appreciate fully the extent to which the machinery of government can be appropriately used to achieve the objectives of policy.

In this context there have been changes in recent years which are a matter for concern. Whilst the Opposition-I was the spokesman at the time-supported the general thrust of the Government's reforms to the Public Service Act the manner in which some of those regulations and changes were implemented has caused some concern. Whilst the Labor Party talks about the need to maintain a cost effective and apolitical Public Service, there is a belief in the Public Service today-particularly in the Senior Executive Service which, I must interpolate, was one of the reforms recommended in the 202nd report and accepted by the Government-that we do not have a truly apolitical Public Service, as has been the tradition of the past. Especially as a result of what is called the MOPS Act, the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, it is now possible for public servants to find a fast track to promotion. This means that a public servant who may have certain political beliefs relating to one government or the other hitches himself to a rising star in the Parliament, gets on to the staff of a Minister, remains there for two or three years and then is parachuted back into the Public Service, into his old department, at a significant higher promotion.

The area where this has been of most concern has been my old Department, the Department of Foreign Affairs. As I understand it, the Department of Foreign Affairs currently supplies in excess of a dozen officers to the staffs of various Ministers around Parliament House. There is not the slightest doubt that all of those officers, at the conclusion of their period of service, will expect to go before the Reappointments Review Committee and receive with reason, because so far every person has achieved this objective, a higher promotion upon their reintegration into their former departments. I do not need to emphasise that this is causing considerable ill will among officers who, through no fault of their own, have not been given the opportunity of parliamentary service. They believe that, for some reason better known to those who make the decisions, they are being seen as somehow inferior to those officers who had the advantage of parliamentary service.

At least in theory the whole emphasis that the Government has placed on selection and promotion involves merit on the one hand and the belief that promotion must be seen to be fair at all times on the other. Unless the Public Service Board is able to determine that an officer has been promoted because he or she is the best person for the job, we are quite clearly opening up a situation in which others will question the veracity of and basis for those decisions. That is what is happening today. If we have a position where an officer who is in a line management position is unable at least to appeal or have his or her merits compared with those of the officer who has been selected following ministerial or parliamentary service, clearly that person is right in saying that the concept of promotion on merit is at best questionable and that possibly, in reality, such appointments may not be made on merit at all.

I would go so far as to suggest that over a period of two or three years-the present Government is now in its second term-possibly hundreds of public servants would expect to go back to their departments on promotion, and the officers with whom they are competing will have no access whatsoever to the machinery which determines at what level those people will be reappointed. As a result of representations my colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) and I made on this matter, an additional officer from the department to which the promotion is to be made has been appointed to the review committee. That is some improvement, but it is not enough. We suggest that the Government consider seriously an amendment to the MOPS Act which will ensure promotion on merit. Promotion to the Senior Executive Service in particular from ministerial staff must be seen by all as fair and subject to appeal.

Another matter to which I would like to draw the attention of the House, in relation to the efficiency and effectiveness of government, is the growing belief in the Public Service that the Parliament and government do not appreciate the extraordinary administrative costs which new programs can introduce, and makes the application of policy so much more difficult. I wonder, for example, whether anyone has really considered the number of review mechanisms now in place which effectively negate the ability of the most competent Public Service managers to make decisions and be responsible for what they do. Every decision made by a manager is subject to the freedom of information legislation, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, appeals to the courts, the review process of the Parliament and the Auditor-General, and last but not least the ever present problems of unions, and staff associations. I would go so far as to suggest that there is no prospect of departmental managers having the freedom to act to any degree comparable with a manager in even the most inefficient private sector concern because of the number of reviews we have permitted through the Parliament, the Department of Finance and the Public Service board, in addition to the requirements in various legislation.

Is it any wonder that at the end of the day a senior manager in the Public Service can honestly say: `You do not give me the power to make the decisions, and without that power they simply will not be made.'? Therefore, it is incumbent upon the Government, essentially, to ensure that in its efforts to protect both the pubic purse on the one hand and human rights on the other it also takes into account the fact that we must have in place an approach to public administration which means that officers who are responsible for making decisions are capable of doing so, and if they make the wrong decisions their future in the Public Service of course must be considered in that light.

I regret that the recommendation in the 202nd report which has been taken up-that members of the Senior Executive Service should not see tenure as guaranteed-has not been extended to the Third Division as recommended by the Public Accounts Committee. I am surprised and saddened that the Government did not have the courage when it introduced that reform to apply the same principle in relation to tenure to the entire Public Service, not just to the Senior Executive Service.

Another point raised by the honourable member for Canberra which is worth noting is that we are concerned that the staff appraisal program has not been put into place as recommended some four years ago. It is perfectly clear to me that as a result of trade union activity, especially that of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, the Government so far has been frightened away from what is quite clearly a logical and correct path, that is, requiring a performance measurement on all public servants, especially those who are involved in the administration of programs and whose responsibility therefore involves the cost effectiveness of the programs administered by specific departments. The failure of the Government to grasp the reality of an effective staff appraisal system is not acceptable to me or the Opposition. The Public Service Board's introduction at last into six departments of a staff appraisal pilot program is merely a means of delaying for yet another few years effective action in this direction.

Finally, I draw attention to another point raised by the Committee. That is my concern in relation to the approaches taken by the Government in regard to questions of industrial democracy. Honourable members may be aware that last week a Commissioner of the Public Service Board, a Mr Glenn, in an address to an industrial relations seminar, made the point that he was particularly concerned about the impact of industrial democracy in the Public Service because he saw that as being yet another area for possible disagreement with the trade unions involved. He believed that the trade unions were now seeing industrial democracy questions as a means by which they could effectively infiltrate the decision-making processes of departments. I want to make it absolutely clear that the Opposition will not tolerate a distinction of this nature, where the trade unions are encouraged to believe that they have a locus standi in the employer-employee relationship, standing between the Government on one hand and its public servants on the other. Their responsibility relates to terms and conditions of employment. They should not be involved with the decision-making process within departments.

I warn the Government that, unless it is prepared to constrain this continuous and insidious growth of trade union activity in the Public Service, it will not simply have a situation such as we have at present where the public sector is possibly the most highly unionised group in the Australian work force, but will have a worse situation, as we experienced two years ago when we had a range of strikes across this country over salaries. The ACOA in Victoria explicitly stated that its object was to take from government the control of the Government's own work force. The Government may be prepared to tolerate that sort of behaviour, but the Opposition is not and I am certain neither are the Australian people who are required through taxation to pay for the salaries of these people who under certain circumstances, often unjustifiably, are not prepared to work.

I welcome the report tabled by the Public Accounts Committee today and I endorse the observations made by the honourable member for Canberra. I note with some concern the fact that the Government has not gone as far as it should have in relation to the recommendations contained initially in the 202nd report, and I trust some speedy decisions will be taken on the outstanding matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Government will not oppose the amendments requested by the Senate to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. On 6 May 1986, the Senate, in Committee of the Whole, voted to delete clauses 25 to 27 of the Bill. These clauses referred to the compulsory maturation provisions for spirits. The deletion of these clauses is described curiously as a request by the Senate to the House of Representatives. I might mention, however, that our acceptance of the amendments at this time does not necessarily mean that we will not pursue the removal of compulsory maturation from the Spirits Act at a later day. The Government remains of the view that that Act is no longer the appropriate medium for this type of control; nor is it convinced by the arguments presented in the Senate for the retention of compulsory maturation. The opposition in the Senate to the removal of compulsory maturation appeared to be centred on two issues: One, the need to provide for adequate labelling of spirits to ensure consumer protection; and, two, the need to ensure that imported spirits do not disrupt the domestic market. I am pleased to say that the government has already introduced initiatives which, when complete, will satisfy the objection on this issue.

First, on the question of labelling I am advised that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has completed negotiations with his State and Territory counterparts on a co-operative agreement to adopt uniform standards applicable to food and beverages sold in Australia. I understand that the draft agreement has been circulated to Premiers, with a view to early implementation. Implementation of this agreement will mean the application of a single, uniform standard throughout Australia which will require labelling of spirits in such a way as to ensure consumer protection.

With regard to the question of imported spirits disrupting the market, the Government announced in its economic and rural policy statement on 15 April 1986 that a working party is being convened to consider compliance with Australian standards by imported food and beverages. This working party will aim to develop appropriate arrangements to ensure uniformity between imported and locally produced products, including spirits. I therefore give notice that when the Government is satisfied that the Opposition's concerns have been met, the amendments to the Spirits Act to remove compulsory maturation will again be introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bounties Bill 1986 is an attempt by the Government to update certain procedures by which bounties are administered within Government decisions. It might be useful to the House to recall the broad process under which bounties are payable. Firstly, a reference is made to the Industries Assistance Commission, which presents a draft report, followed by a full report to the Government through the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who is responsible for the IAC. The IAC looks at the industry concerned-its problems, commitments and expectations for the future-and makes recommendations to the Government as to how the future of that industry would best be handled.

SPEECH.PARA: As long as Australia has been a federation the debate on free trade versus protectionism has been alive and well. We have heard about things called wets and dries today. The original political parties in Australia were based on free traders or protectionists, so our ancestors are well represented by their product. I am sure that the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) would understand that; he has a great interest in that subject. The Bounties Bill is quite a challenge to the ghosts who stalk the corridors of Canberra, because it is an attempt to take the recommendations of the IAC to Cabinet; for the Cabinet to make a decision; and for that decision to be brought into effect not by the Parliament as such but by ministerial gazettal. The Opposition opposes that concept. We will move amendments to the Bill in the Senate to bring certain changes and will oppose it at the second reading in this House. We find that the Government's proposition not to follow the ordinary parliamentary processes is not acceptable. It is a long time since it attempted to bypass the powers of the Executive Government and the powers of the Parliament as blatantly as this.

A sense of history comes to the fore in relation to the role of the Executive Government. As a former member of an Executive Government, I have no doubt that the trappings of the back bench and parliamentary committees can be wearisome. The processes of the Parliament can be slow and arduous, but every one of us is elected to do a job; to represent our constituency, to have the ability to put a point of view in this House and to know what goes on in relation to IAC reports and the responses to them. The debate on protectionism versus free trade has not drawn packed houses here for a long time. It is not the area it used to be, but there are more names on the speakers list today than there used to be. Members of parliament have a renewed interest in the question. How one goes about the maintenance of Australian industry, the development of industry policy, the infant industry argument, the general protectionist argument and the development of various lines are things which ought to be debated in this House, not subject to gazettal by the Government.

I find, from experience in the former Executive Government, in Opposition and as a general businessman before I came here, that it is more beneficial to the nation as a whole to encourage debate in this whole area rather than to use the Parliament as a rubber stamp process on the assumption that members of parliament are not interested in the matter and therefore to take away the essence of parliamentary control, as this Bill in essence will do, as I see it. The time taken up in debate in Parliament is well worth it.

I do not find the retrospective action referred to in the Bill to be of great concern. If a Government decision is announced, following an IAC report, that bounty will be payable from a certain date, and an amending Bill goes through the House, I fail to see why commercial concerns ought to be materially concerned about that. I am sure that the usual commercial decisions will be made on the basis of the decision that has been announced. That is what has happened in the past; therefore I do not see any great necessity to bring in these new propositions.

It is worth noting that the explanatory memorandum refers to four principal provisions contained in the Bill. The first is a facility to introduce new bounty assistance schemes by bounty notices declared in writing by the Minister, to which I have referred already. The second is a facility to amend bounty schemes by regulation in limited circumstances. In other words, without reference to the Parliament, a scheme can be changed by gazettal. I do not believe that that is appropriate. Funds are voted by this House for things and this proposal is a way in which responsibility for those funds can be bypassed. The amendment may be trivial or short term; nevertheless, the Parliament has a responsibility which ought to be met.

Thirdly, there is a facility to revoke bounty notices. I will refer later to some considerations in relation to that, because it is apparent that the facility to revoke is inhibited by this legislation, in the sense that both Houses must act to recoup, which is not the most appropriate way of administration. With the proposed process the administration would be allowed to run a bit, instead of the Minister being badgered to bring in the various revocation notices. Fourthly, there is a range of administrative powers and requirements designed to standardise the administration of bounty schemes. Frankly, having been the Minister responsible for those areas, I know that the amount of legislation that comes through is considerable, but that is no excuse for the Minister responsible to say: `Look, let us slam it into the Gazette-she'll do, boys. If they want to revoke it, they can revoke it in the normal way'. The procedure outlined is not appropriate.

I wish to make a few points in relation to those procedures. Part II of the Bill provides that the Minister may, by notice in writing published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, specify a scheme in accordance with which bounty will be payable on the production of goods. A scheme may be retrospective for no more than six months and it may be modified, extended or restricted by regulation or revoked by notice. Under clause 10 schemes would be subject to disallowance in the same manner as regulations, except that the relevant statutory period for giving and resolving a notice of motion would be reduced from 15 to seven sitting days.

Under clause 11 all or part of the bounty paid under a disallowed scheme would be repayable only if both Houses of Parliament so determined. Although the provisions for disallowance of a notice would give each House a power of veto over any bounty scheme, the Bill would severely restrict parliamentary control over such schemes. Only a whole section could be disallowed. The Bill is drafted in such a way that each House would be forced to accept or reject the whole of the scheme. As a minimum requirement for proper parliamentary control the Bill should be amended so that any part of a scheme can be disallowed. There would be no power of amendment, whereas at present each House may amend a bounty Bill. Under this Bill the House would not be able to pass an amendment to a scheme and would be forced to disallow any defective provision, even if disallowance of part of a scheme were permitted. Consideration should be given to an amendment to the Bill to give effect to any amendment of a scheme agreed to by both Houses. That will be the subject of one of the Opposition's amendments in the Senate.

The House would be inhibited in disallowing an existing scheme. By the time the House is able to disallow a scheme it may have been in operation for months and large amounts of money may have been paid out. In these circumstances, the House may well feel inhibited to exercise its powers of disallowance. The consent of both Houses would be necessary for reclaiming the payments. Once a scheme had been disallowed by one House, the consent of both Houses would be required to reclaim all or part of any of the payments made under the scheme. This would be a further inhibiting factor in the exercising of due parliamentary control over the public purse.

Disallowance may be circumvented. There are a number of methods by which a government which is determined to put a scheme into operation may circumvent the disallowance provisions. I would say that it would have to be bloody-minded in relation to it. The scheme may be brought into operation perhaps at the beginning of a long adjournment or recess and then revoked or replaced by a scheme the same in substance before either House has a chance to disallow it. The Houses may be powerless to veto a short term scheme. Revocation and replacement of a scheme by a single notice, or a single provision in a notice, would force a House to accept either the new or the old scheme because the disallowance of the new scheme would have the effect of reviving the revoked scheme. The latter problem can be overcome by an amendment requiring that a notice of revocation contain only the revocation. Because of these factors, which would also apply to alterations of schemes by regulation, the Bill would significantly reduce parliamentary control over bounty schemes.

Because of those factors, which are given in some detail, the Opposition is opposed to the Bill. We like to see and to encourage in this House, as I have said before, a full debate on questions of bounty, of tariffs and of quotas. They are as relevant today as they were in 1901. The question of the balance of payments has recently been addressed as a major problem. The answers were addressed by a senator who is a Minister in a way which harked back to the old protectionist days. In the House at Question Time today, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that that was not his view. So, right up to today, there is a conflict about the more open approach to economics, and the more contained and protectionist approach is burying its head in the bosom of the Government as much as it is in the whole of Australia. Because of that, debates in relation to the bounty should be encouraged, and not discouraged as the Bill attempts to do, and the interests of the public of Australia should be encouraged through these debates in the future. I would hope, as I am sure the Minister would, that more members of this House will take a role in these debates than do at present.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) made the point, which I support, that the Opposition has strong reservations about the workings of this particular piece of legislation. Even though I feel positive about at least the intentions of the Bill, it seems to me to have two really broad intentions. First, it has the intention of speeding up the administrative process for the introduction of bounties. I do not think there is any need to tell the House that that process needs to be accelerated. Secondly, the implication of this Bill is that the Government prefers the system of bounties to the system of tariffs as a form of industry assistance. That is not spelled out, of course, in the legislation. It would be a horrifying thought to contemplate that the Government was taking the view that it should extend the operation of bounties and retain the levels of tariff protection that Australia already has as a form of industry assistance. To be honest, and I always endeavour to be that, I do not think it is the intention of the Government to pursue industry policy in quite that way.

There is certainly a broadly based argument that I think is now becoming accepted in the community that bounties are a preferable form of industry assistance to the tariff where, of course, budgetary considerations will allow a government to choose the option of bounties over the option of tariffs. Although bounties were first introduced into Australia in about 1907, traditionally Australian governments have preferred the tariff as a form of assistance rather than bounties. However, there is a growing realisation now in industry, commerce and throughout the Australian community that tariffs are the worst kind of assistance that can be given to industry. Tariffs wrap industry up in cotton wool and militate against the essential process of restructuring-a process that Australian industry has not gone through sufficiently and which is one of many reasons why Australian industry has failed to meet international competition in the way that it should have.

If the Government, the Parliament and the community take a view that certain industries should be encouraged and assisted, my contention very strongly is that where it is possible in budgetary terms to make a choice, the choice should be in favour of bounties rather than tariffs. There are three basic reasons for choosing bounties over tariffs. First of all, in the case of bounties the cost of the industry assistance is explicit. It is written into the Budget. There is a clear statement of the cost of that assistance. In other words, the community can readily understand, if it chooses to look at the figures, what the costs as well as the benefits, should there be any benefits, of the industry assistance really are. In the case of tariffs there is no visibility in the form of assistance given. Those costs are hidden. Because those costs are hidden, often we fail to appreciate the damage that protection through tariffs can do, and thus only look at what apparently and simplistically are seen to be the benefits.

It was a former member for Wakefield, Bert Kelly, who brought these arguments so forcefully to this chamber and, indeed, to the Australian community. He did a great service by ensuring that people in Australia understood these simple arguments much more clearly than had been the case before. It is a tribute to him that his arguments are now so broadly accepted by members of this Parliament, including people on the other side. As I said, there is a great deal to be said for the costs of assistance through bounties being visible rather than being invisible in the form of tariffs.

The second argument in favour of bounties over tariffs is that bounties avoid a `consumption distortion', as economists would say. When tariffs are introduced they increase the prices to consumers of the goods which are imported into Australia. In other words, by increasing that price clearly one will distort consumption patterns which should normally be set by the processes of supply and demand in the market-place. It does not just distort consumption patterns in favour of domestically produced products which, of course, is the intention of the tariff, but also distorts consumption patterns in favour of other goods and services altogether and away from the good that may be protected by way of the tariff. In other words, resource allocation is being seriously influenced by government decisions and not by the operation of the market-place. Where one intervenes in that sort of way, it must be understood that the long term consequence of that decision is ultimately to reduce the standard of living of the Australian people and Australian consumers. Where tariffs are used as a form of assistance and consumption patterns are distorted, the effect is for the Government to intervene in the interests perhaps of management and perhaps of employees in particular firms but not to intervene in the broader interests of the community and in the interests of the consumers. It is my contention that it is the broader interests of the community and the consumers which should be put well before the interests of certain vested interest groups.

The third argument in favour of bounties is that when tariffs are introduced as a form of assistance they increase costs to the downstream consumers of those goods which are imported. This is a point which is repeatedly made by the National Farmers Federation and by Australia's rural community. Their contention is that the operation of the tariff system in Australia is increasing costs on Australian farms by, on average, $9,000 per farm per year. Farmers are forced to import various pieces of equipment, pay high levels of tariff and protection on them, which in turn substantially increases their production costs, and they cannot recoup that cost through the domestic market-place by increasing prices. They have to go out into the world market, where they are not able to pass on the increased costs resulting from the tariff. In many respects the emphasis on tariffs has made Australian industry uncompetitive, whereas bounties would eliminate much of the cost to downstream users. Although those costs would be borne by taxpayers, by the use of bounties we would be giving the broader interests of Australian industry the opportunity to compete, which it is having the greatest difficulty doing, as everyone in Australia must, by now, know.

The use of bounties, though preferable to tariffs, must not detract from the simple fact that any form of assistance, be it through the taxpayers' pocket or through additional costs to consumers by way of the tariff, is less preferable to a government taking hard decisions which would make our industries more competitive. That is the bottom line. That is what government industry policy should concentrate on, not just new and imaginative ways of propping up industries which are not able to compete.

These arguments have been well canvassed in this Parliament over the last three years. There is no doubt that the failure by government to take the hard decisions to make Australian industry more competitive is one of the reasons why investment in Australia is now depressed and we are having great balance of payments difficulties. A recent survey produced by the Business Council of Australia shows why there has been such a fall-off in investment in Australia and, in turn, says something about the failure of Australian industries to compete. If our industries were more competitive, naturally there would be considerably more investment in them.

Members of the Business Council have pointed to a number of different factors which are discouraging investment. First, they point to labour costs. They argue that Australian industry, particularly Australian manufacturers, are paying labour bills which do not bear any relationship to their capacity to pay those bills, and indeed, equally importantly, the international circumstances in which those industries operate. The Government argues that the growth in wage costs has not been very great during its term of office but, as members of the Business Council have been pointing out, wage inflation in Australia has been substantially higher than the level of wage inflation in a number of major countries. If wage inflation and labour cost structure are higher than in other countries, one will have major difficulties in being able to compete.

The Business Council has also pointed to the very great burden manufacturing industry is now carrying because of the extraordinary escalation in the cost of borrowing money-in other words, in the level of interest rates. As the Council has said, the level of interest rates is `a major barrier' to investment in our industries.

Further, the Business Council has pointed to the very high level of taxation that business must pay in Australia and the fact that that taxation burden is only increasing under the tax package put to this Parliament by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The new fringe benefits tax will militate against a whole range of industries in Australia. The tax will be borne by our car industry, which will lose production and jobs as a result. The capital gains tax, which was introduced only recently, again will impose further costs on Australian industry. Also, the level of company taxation has been increased from 46 to 49 per cent at a time when our major trading partners are actually reducing their levels of company tax-in the case of the United Kingdom to 35 per cent and in the United States of America to 33 per cent. The fiscal cost of capital for Australian business is very much higher than the fiscal cost of capital in other major competitor countries. That cost has been made all the higher in the last 12 months by the Government's decision to abolish the investment allowance.

Hard decisions are needed to try to reduce this cost structure-not just bounties and tariffs, which has been the traditional method we have chosen to avoid making those hard decisions. Hard decisions have got to be made to reduce the tax burden, to reduce the level of interest rates, to get our labour cost structure into some order so that it bears some relationship to the capacity of the economy to compete in the international market-place. Though I welcome the general Government emphasis towards bounties and away from tariffs, my disappointment is great that the Government has not taken the hard decisions it really needs to take.

When the Government introduces measures to impose bounties or increase tariffs, it is very important that the Parliament scrutinise that legislation, and that the representatives of the people are able to understand what costs the Government is placing on them as well as any benefits that may flow from their decisions. This piece of legislation-this is why the Opposition so strongly opposes it-severely restricts parliamentary control over the whole bounty system. I make a couple of brief points about how that happens.

The new system of bounties will operate on the basis of notices placed in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette by the Minister. Of course, the Parliament will have the power of disallowance, as it does in the case of regulations, although the period where those notices lie on the table will be substantially shorter than in the case of regulations. This raises a whole series of issues which need to be canvassed. First, it should be pointed out that under this legislation only a whole notice-not part-can be disallowed. The Bill is drafted in such a way that each House, the Senate and the House of Representatives, should be forced to accept or reject the whole of any scheme. As a minimum requirement for proper parliamentary control, the Bill should be amended so that any part of a scheme may be disallowed. Under this legislation one only has the option of disallowing the whole thing, whether it or parts of it are good or not.

Secondly, and related to that point, under this legislation there is no power of amendment. The Parliament cannot just amend a particular bounty scheme. It either has to accept it all or accept none of it whatever. Once more that provides an obstacle to parliamentary control, scrutiny and rectification of poor legislation, or in this case poor notices and proposals. Thirdly, the Houses-the Senate and the House of Representatives-will be inhibited in a number of ways from disallowing an existing scheme. By the time a House is able to disallow a scheme, the scheme may have been in operation for months and large amounts of money paid out to the beneficiaries of the bounty. The House may well feel inhibited from exercising its power of disallowance if large amounts of money have already been paid out. I do not think anybody could argue with that.

Fourthly, the consent of both Houses of Parliament will be necessary under this legislation for reclaiming payments. Once a scheme has been disallowed by one House, the consent of both Houses will be required to reclaim all or part of any payments made under the scheme. This will be a further inhibition on the use of the disallowance power. There are some very real restrictions here on the power of the Parliament, which traditionally has been responsible for the introduction of bounties and other forms of industry assistance. The Opposition is deeply concerned about the way in which the Government is, in effect, determined to circumvent that traditional power of the Australian Parliament. After all, under the Westminster system Parliament's power initially came through its power over the purse strings. The English civil war was fought over that very issue. It is rather ironical that in the case of this legislation the Australian Government, a Labor Government, to use the analogy of the English civil war, is taking the role of the King by giving the Executive additional power over the power of Parliament, the body that represents the people.

It is extremely ironical that the Labor Party, which always professes to be the party of the people, should for some reason or other choose to distort decision-making, in this case in favour of the Executive and away from the people. There is no better example of that than clause 54 of this legislation, which relates to the provision of funds for the payment of bounties. Under clause 54 money for bounties is automatically appropriated. That gives the Executive the power to appropriate by delegated legislation. I do not think that any members of this Parliament, if they seriously thought about this legislation and if he understood this legislation, could condone a decision by a government to force upon this Parliament the appropriation of funds without proper parliamentary consideration. There are two aspects to this. On the one hand, there is decision-making by the Minister, by the Executive, and not by the Parliament in relation to the provision of assistance to Australian industries. That, I would have thought, should be a matter properly debated in the Parliament and considered by the representatives of the people. On the other hand, under this legislation, the Executive-the Minister-is able to appropriate funds, once more without referral in each individual case to the Parliament.

Whilst I can understand the desire of the Government to accelerate the procedures for the introduction and payment of bounties, I could never condone a government which chooses to undermine the power of Parliament, which is ultimately the power of the people of Australia. Their representatives are being cast aside by this legislation and those powers are being rather ruthlessly taken over by the Executive. I would be very disappointed if some members of the Labor Party were not to join with the Opposition in opposing this legislation, bearing in mind the long tradition of the Labor Party in supporting the whole system of parliamentary democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Bounties Bill. I do so for a number of reasons. It needs to be said at the outset that under existing bounty arrangements bounty assistance to industry can be introduced only by way of an Act of Parliament. It needs to be emphasised that many changes to bounty assistance are what we could call quite non-contentious, and enjoy bipartisan support. It is in this sense that the Government believes that too often a very lengthy, inordinate amount of time is spent by the Parliament discussing measures which, as I have said, in large part enjoy bipartisan support, are straight forward and are non-contentious. It is to this end that the Bill before the House proposes that the introduction of bounty assistance should be made through a ministerial notification process. The process would ensure-and I stress this point-parliamentary scrutiny through the provision for a general disallowance right by the Parliament. That function of the Parliament is safeguarded, but on the other hand these provisions will save the Parliament considerable, often unnecessary and inefficiently spent time debating numerous Bills and amendments to Bills which have to do with bounties.

SPEECH.PARA: Part II of the Bill proposes that bounty schemes be implemented by bounty notices which would be declared in writing by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. Such schemes would, of course, be introduced only following receipt of an appropriate report from the Industries Assistance Commission on the particular industry or industries concerned. The new arrangements proposed by this Bill will eliminate-this is one of the great advantages of this Bill-the need for what is, in effect, the retrospective operation of bounties. There is a real problem with the current arrangements in that they often provide for bounties to be paid in what can be called a retrospective way. That is a point which was well illustrated by the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) in his second reading speech when he referred to bounties on metal-working machines and robots. The legislation to implement those measures was introduced in this Parliament on 11 September 1985. It received royal assent on 22 November 1985. But because it operated from 1 July 1985 there was a delay of nearly six months before the bounty could be paid and those Australian producers in receipt of that bounty could gain the benefit.

One of the major benefits, as I see it, of this Bill before the House is that it will remove entirely that element of what could only be called retrospectivity, where there are delays in the passage of the legislation through this House and as a result a decision to pay a bounty is held in abeyance for many months to the detriment of the industry concerned, and in that sense all Australian industry. In many ways this is a very important Bill for Australian industry and I know that it will be welcomed by those industries which in the future might receive bounty assistance.

In addition to the changes I have already mentioned parts III, IV and V of the Bill will standardise the administrative provisions for all bounty schemes, making for a much more efficient administration of bounties and a much better delivery of benefits to the respective industries. Clause 8 of the Bill will also improve the operation and the efficiency of bounty programs by enabling changes in implementation to be made on the basis of changes which have occurred for technological or economic circumstances. Again, the Minister in his second reading speech provided a very good example of the book bounty introduced in 1969. That industry has seen many and varied technological changes, with the result that the original bounty provisions in many ways are exceedingly complicated and in some ways no longer relevant to that industry. The effect of this legislation in the future will be to simplify those procedures and to allow the Government, through a government bounty program, to keep up to date with changing technology and economic procedures.

The new procedures which are proposed in this Bill highlight the role of bounties as a key instrument in industry policy. As I have said, the new proposals will ensure that the introduction and amendment of bounty programs are undertaken in a much more effective and efficient way. In this sense they should enhance the very crucial role that bounties play in providing direct support to Australian industry against import competition. It is worthy of note that there are currently 18 bounty schemes in operation in Australia. The most recent of those was that for metal-working machines and robots which became effective, as I said, from 1 July 1985, being passed by this Parliament in November 1985.

It has to be said that, as a mechanism for providing protection and/or incentives for Australian industry, bounties are in many ways preferable to tariffs. That was a line of argument taken up by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) in his contribution. There are a number of reasons why bounties are preferable to tariffs. The first of those is that bounties actually have to be paid for out of Budget appropriations. That means that they are obvious, identifiable and subject to regular review. Over time they must continue to be relevant and necessary, and that makes them considerably superior to tariffs, which can be hidden away unbeknown to the public as a hidden form of protection.

The second reason I think bounties are preferable to tariffs is that bounties relate the national interest in a sense directly to the cost of protecting or providing incentives to the industry in question. In comparison, a tariff selectively adds to the cost of goods which are imported to Australia whereas, with a bounty, assistance is given to an industry but the cost of providing that assistance is not selective or sectoral, but is spread throughout the Australian community through a Budget appropriation.

The third point that needs to be emphasised, and it is one made by the honourable member for Mayo, is that bounties in their operation often have a deflationary or price reducing effect on the economy, whereas tariffs are most frequently inflationary in their effect on the economy. Bounties reduce the cost of production to Australian industry and hence often enable the price of a product to be reduced when it hits the markets. Tariffs, by their very nature, add to the cost of goods and hence provide opportunities and incentives to add to the price which a consumer or retailer eventually pays.

The fourth and final point about bounties and tariffs is that tariffs in so many ways simply represent a tax on exports. The clearest example of the way in which tariffs tax exports from this country is to be found in the operations of primary producers, a major exporting group who are contributing close to 40 per cent of total export income. As the honourable member for Mayo remarked, many of the direct and indirect inputs into agriculture in Australia are heavily costed because of tariffs on imports into this country. Some of the obvious examples in relation to the tariff question in the farm sector-the question of taxing inputs and then taxing exports-relate to such things as farm chemicals, agricultural machinery and farm tractors. I will come back to the question of agricultural machinery, implements and tractors because this Government has in fact taken a number of initiatives to reduce tariffs on those inputs and replace those tariffs with bounties, thereby reducing costs to the Australian primary producers and allowing our exports to be more competitive on the export market.

It needs to be said that since coming to office this Government has implemented a wide range of measures to assist Australian industry, and I will touch on some of those in a moment. Included amongst those measures is the provision of bounties to selected industries. We have introduced bounties to assist industries to become more efficient and be able to compete better in the domestic market and, in the long term, to export. We have introduced bounties in respect of the computer hardware and software industries. We have extended the shipbuilding bounty. As I said before, we have introduced a bounty for metal-working machine tools and robots. We have introduced bounties on agricultural machinery and grain harvesters. The last two bounties have been of great assistance to primary producers.

As a member who represents a rural and provincial seat in this Parliament, I have been particularly pleased at the progress which this Government-the Hawke Government-has made in replacing the tariffs on agricultural inputs. I have mentioned farm machinery. In the recent major economic statement to this Parliament, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) announced that the Government would be providing a bounty on agricultural machinery. That decision will cost some $39m a year. It is a decision, as I have said, which will be of particular benefit to Australia's cropping industries-industries such as the wheat industry, the rice industry and the sugar industry, all of which are presently finding it difficult to compete on international markets. All of those industries appreciate the steps which this Government has taken to substitute tariffs on imports with the provision of bounties to domestic producers and manufacturers.

As previous speakers have mentioned, this Bill opens up the whole question of industry policy, the effectiveness of industry policy and the broad question of bounties versus tariffs. Since coming to office, this Government has endeav- oured, through a range of policy initiatives, to revitalise manufacturing industry in this country. I must say that we have done that with some degree of success and we look forward to further success, further strength and further economic and employment growth in manufacturing industry. We have given manufacturing industry such a high priority in the programs and policies of this Government because manufacturing industry is crucial and will be even more crucial in the future to our ability to compete on world markets. It is crucial to our ability to balance our balance of payments and to boost our export returns, which for so many years in this country have relied virtually totally on the commodity market-on primary production, iron ore, coal and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the Opposition do about it?

—The honourable member for Chifley raises the question of what the Opposition ever did about manufacturing industry or the balance of payments. The answer is that it did not do very much. In fact, if we look back over the last 30 years, of which the Liberal and National parties were in government for 27, we will see that our international trade performance, particularly the performance of our manufacturing sector, was deplorable. In fact, it was probably second to none of every other country. We were the poorest performer in trade terms. In the last 30 years-I have mentioned that 27 of those years were under the policies of the Liberal and National parties-our share of world exports has slipped from 2.6 per cent to 1.2 per cent of world markets. In other words, it has more than halved, and that has occurred in the last 30 years. Whereas back in the 1950s we used to be ranked eighth in terms of exports, we now rank twenty-third or twenty-fourth. The reason for that is that we never had proper policies in place in this country. We had a cargo cult sort of mentality. We thought we would always survive on the back of the sheep or on the back of the grain harvester or by digging coal out of the ground. Our contribution in terms of exports from the manufacturing sector was absolutely abysmal. It is no wonder it was abysmal because manufacturing industry was never encouraged by the macroeconomic setting in this country. In fact, it did quite the opposite. We suffered enormously from high protection and high tariffs. The old McEwen and National Party view was that we could always survive under a highly protected industry and that wool, wheat, sugar, coal and iron ore would pay the way. As a result, our standard of living has fallen.
—We never developed an expertise that was exportable.

—I thank the Minister for Science for making the very valuable point that we never in this country developed any expertise, technology, brain matter or services which could be exported. We were always prepared to rely on what we could simply dig up or grow. It is worth making a comparison of the results. Whereas in the last 30 years other countries-and I mention North America, Japan, Europe and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development as a whole-have increased their manufacturing export performance by 50 per cent, ours has actually declined. Of course, this is the main reason why we are today suffering what I consider to be serious problems in our balance of payments. That is why this Bill and questions of industry policy are crucial to Australia's ability to compete in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned that we have taken measures and introduced bounties and so on to reduce the cost of inputs to commodity industries. We have assisted those industries. However, as I said, we have to do a lot more to assist manufacturing industry directly in this country. I just want to run through some of the things that we have done. Let me outline what we have done to assist manufacturing industry development in this country. We introduced and developed the highly successful steel plan. That is something which is contributing to Australian exports at the moment. We have developed the motor vehicle plan, which over time will produce a more efficient and more export oriented Australian motor vehicle industry. I have mentioned the range of bounty assistance that we have brought in for computer hardware and software, metalworking machine tools, robots and so on. We have also developed a growth strategy for the communications industry, and that is crucial as we change the focus of that industry from the domestic to the international market-place. We have put in our new sectoral plan for the heavy engineering industry. These are just some of the things we have done for industry development.

What about the crucial question of technology and business efficiency? I want to highlight some of the measures in this area and perhaps the Minister for Science, who is in the House, may comment on some of them when he is summing up the second reading debate. We introduced the 150 per cent tax deduction for research and development expenditure. I am pleased to say that that is something which has taken up pretty vigorously by Australian industry. More than $100m of concessions will be provided this year in an area in which Australia has been sadly lacking in the past. We have always been prepared to rely simply on the government research dollar and the private sector has not been putting the dough into research and development so that we can pick up export markets. So we have taken action to lift Australia's low level of research and development. We have also provided additional funds to Australia's industrial research and development incentives scheme. We have increased funding to the Australian Industry Development Corporation to ensure that a capital base exists for the expansion of Australian industry.

In conclusion, I would like to refer to some of the things we have done in the overall industry environment. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has set up new machinery to review business regulations. We are starting to get to a stage where business regulations in Australia, which are excessive at the moment, can be reduced. The Minister has approval to remove State purchasing agreements. This has been overdue in this country for many years. We have seen the establishment and the extension of management investment companies in this country, and again that has been vital to the high-tech, brain power area where job growth and exports will be so important in the future. We have improved the anti-dumping procedures. I think that we could probably go a bit further. However, we have made some improvements and I hope that we make some further improvements in the future.

I conclude by saying that we have done these things in the industry environment. In the macro-economic environment, we have provided a framework in which manufacturing profitability and manufacturing employment in this country have now recovered. They need to recover further. We have employment levels back to where they were before the 1981-82 recession. I know from my own electorate of Bendigo that very strong investment and employment growth is occurring in manufacturing industry in that electorate. That is occurring because of some of the benefits which the accord has given to producers in this country.

We have seen industrial disputes at their lowest level in Australia for 19 years. That is not a bad record of achievement and it is a pity that the Opposition does not acknowledge it. We have seen the strongest employment growth in Australia for 20 years. That is not a bad achievement either if one looks at it objectively. We have seen the restoration of profit shares in this country to levels which were left behind back in the 1960s. The profit share is there, so companies can invest, put money into research and new technology, employ more people and pick up export markets. Perhaps most importantly, through the accord we have seen real labour unit costs reduced to their lowest level for 10 years. That has set the framework. Manufacturing industry is largely taking up that challenge and that will be to the long term benefit of Australians, Australia's export performance and Australia's standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me bring it right into perspective. This is a Government which put together a passenger motor vehicle plan-the Button plan-which I and many on this side of the Parliament supported very strongly. It was a very good plan. Mr Deputy Speaker, when we talk about the Australian motor manufacturing industry remember that we are talking about something that is not just the production of cars, trucks and buses. I happen to believe that Australia needs two fundamental things in order to have any defence capacity: One is an Australian indigenous steel industry owned by Australia for Australia and the other is a passenger motor vehicle manufacturing capacity which can be utilised for the defence of this country.

Here we have it: The Parliament has gone dry on both sides of the House, pursuing economic purity which I think is politically wrong and is also about the worst thing this country wants at this point in time. Why is it that we have to clothe ourselves in the white robes of economic purity while, as a result of the misguided policies emanating from this Parliament, thousands of our fellow Australians are losing their jobs? Let me bring it into context because if ever there were a timely announcement to be made in this debate on bounties--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member for Denison that this is not a general debate on manufacturing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear beyond doubt that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) left this country knowing that this bounty legislation was in the pipeline. In that context, I refer to two statements which appeared in our national Press today because it seems that either our Prime Minister has been stricken with jetlag or, alternatively, something has gone radically wrong--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I trust that those statements are related in some way to the bounty legislation.

—Absolutely. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, will pick it in one; some duller members of the Hawke socialist Government will still be scratching their heads three hours later. On page 1 of today's Australian is an article headed `Hawke promises less market protection'. SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, promised yesterday to reduce protection for the footwear, clothing and textile industries and give imports more of the market while also announcing a joint Australia-China ministerial committee on trade and economic relations.
