Why do we have that situation when the Government still has before it an Industries Assistance Commission report which talks about 20,000 jobs being lost in the textile, clothing and footwear industries? For the benefit of the Hawke socialist Government, which says that it believes in equal opportunity and affirmative action, most of the jobs lost are those of female workers, 80 per cent of whom are ethnic female workers.

Are those workers going to be supported by a bounty? Is the proposal that we move from a tariff situation? That eight-year textile, clothing and footwear industries plan was brought in by a Liberal Government, not a Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —And National Party, too.

—The National Party of Australia was involved right up to the hilt, and rightly so. On 15 August 1980 that very great Australian, the Rt Hon. Sir Phillip Lynch, announced the eight-year program for the textile, clothing and footwear industries. From 3 November 1980 until 9 March 1983, a dark day, when the Hawke socialist Government took over, I was honoured to be the Minister assisting Sir Phillip Lynch in the industry and commerce portfolio. I was further honoured to chair on his behalf both the Textiles and Apparel Industry Advisory Council and the Footwear Industry Advisory Council. My colleague and very good friend the shadow Minister and honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who is at the table, will remember those days. When we brought in that plan we said to one part of the Australian manufacturing sector: `Here is an eight-year plan for you to get your house in order, to become efficient and to be able to compete. We want you to have that plan in time to go ahead'. We did not say that, at the end of eight years, protection was going to be reduced. I believe this is relevant, Mr Deputy Speaker, because how do you link together a Bill which the Government says is to give bounties to support Australian manufacturing a prime ministerial statement made in Manila saying that the footwear, clothing and textiles industries can look forward to having their protection cut out? It is relevant that I try to bring these two themes together.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that we cannot have tariffs. I do not know why tariffs are so unfashionable these days. Tariffs were not so unfashionable to Chifley. They were not so unfashionable to Menzies. They were not so unfashionable to McEwen. Tariffs applied when Australian manufacturing industry was providing employment for between one-quarter and one-third of our total work force. Today, in this dry madness, this dry mania, which seems to have overtaken the entire political scene we say: `Economic purity first, jobs second'. We are told: `We want you to buy Australian'. How are the Australian footwear, clothing and textile industries to survive in terms of the massive competition from cheap imports, which this Australian Prime Minister, this man who prides himself on his patriotism, has told us to look out for? The Prime Minister is saying that if the Hawke socialist Government gets another term of office-and it will not-he will cut all protection for Australian footwear, clothing and textile manufacturers. That is it in a nutshell. The Government wants Australia to become a net importer. It wants Australians to be running around in imported clothes, with imported shoes on their feet and driving imported motor vehicles.

I have not yet seen the figures, but I will be very interested to do so, of car sales in Australia which were due to come out today. I will be particularly interested to see how the Button plan is working. It is part of the inconsistency of this Government that when that car plan was introduced-which, I repeat, was supported on both sides of the House-and before it has had a chance to do its job, the idiots opposite in the Hawke socialist Government, and their Treasury zealots, are going to tear it out and destroy it with a fringe benefits tax which is the last thing this country wants now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member once again that we are discussing bounty legislation.

—Yes, we are. There is great hilarity opposite from the ranks of Moscow corner because they do not give a damn about Australians being out of jobs. They do not give a damn about a manufacturing sector which employed one in four Australians five years ago whereas today 250,000 ghosts of unemployed manufacturing industry workers are in this chamber right now listening to this debate. It is the bona fides of the Government that I am challenging. The Government brings in legislation which it says-pie in the sky-is bounty-plus legislation. Bounty decisions will be made more quickly and more efficiently. The Minister will decide. They will will not be subject to a parliamentary debate but Parliament will have the right to disallow.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members should countenance that for a moment in the present context. Under this crazy legislation, which this Opposition is rightly opposing, the final fate of every bounty decision will be in the hands of the Australian Democrats. Is that not an interesting example of where we are heading? The power to disallow in the Senate effectively will be in the hands of the Democrats. Without being critical of the Democrats, if their position on bounties is the same as their position on the fringe benefits tax, then heaven help Australian manufacturers. It goes to the core of whether the Australian Labor Party genuinely believes in manufacturing, and it does not. The Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Mr Barry Jones) has the best will in the world. He is keen and enthusiastic. I can remember when I tried to get a micro-electronic industry for Canberra, which would have employed 1,500 people and would have been a $100m investment for the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister went on television and opposed it. The National Semi-Conductor Corporation--

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not going to believe this, Barry.

—Well, he is an old friend. I have no axe to grind with my old friend Rasputin but I have to say that things are different today. I want to know how all these jobs will come from the high technology sunrise industries we are to get. What the Government is doing at the moment is crucifying the Australian manufacturing sector, so I suggest that the Bill is of doubtful value. I would like the Minister to spell out in reply what industries in particular the Government has in mind for bounties. He should tell us now who is to get the bounties, who are to be the beneficiaries of this legislation. It is one thing to say `tariffs are out' and `tariffs are bad'. I suggest that the footwear, clothing and textile industries are a classic example of where tariffs are appropriate. If the Minister does as the Prime Minister said in Manila he will do, namely, chop out all assistance to the footwear, clothing and textile industries, he will go close to beating the massive loss of jobs in those industries which was brought about by the Prime Minister's predecessor Mr Whitlam back in 1974 when he fiddled with the tariffs--
—Slashed them.
—He slashed them across the board by 25 per cent and 90,000 Australians lost their jobs.
—Overnight.
—Order! I remind the honourable member for Gippsland that he is not in his correct seat in the chamber.

—My word, Mr Deputy Speaker, even though he is not in his correct seat, he is an ornament to this House. I predict a very bright future for the honourable member for Gippsland, and wish I were his age and had his ability. The legislation is bad legislation for two fundamental reasons. The first reason is that it bypasses the Parliament on an important issue such as bounties. We have been told-and this is relevant to the argument-that bounties are better than tariffs because firstly, they are cost explicit, secondly, they avoid a consumption distortion and, thirdly, tariffs increase costs to downstream users and consumers. So we are going to go down the bounty way. But what do we do? We make it a bounty system which the Parliament will not have an opportunity to debate as it has had the opportunity ever since bounties were introduced in 1907. That is just before the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) was born.

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament is told to take it or leave it. It cannot amend bounty schemes. It is all in or all out. Effectively that means that it is all in or all out according to the whim of our friends the Australian Democrats in the Senate. What right will any honourable member have to get up and speak effectively on bounties? He will not even have the right to vote if he thinks the bounty is too low in one area or too high in another. He will be told: `Shut up; it is being done by the Executive. Trust me. Throw away your calculators and trust me'. That is the sort of J-curve banana economics we are getting in the Parliament now from a Party which proclaims that it believes in the Parliament. Yet it moves to bypass Parliament. It will not even give the Parliament the option to amend. Is that what a Parliament is about, Mr Deputy Speaker? I appeal to your wisdom and the wisdom of others.

Talking of Moscow brings to mind that booklet on the fringe benefits tax that has been sent around the country. It has 56 pages, but the legislation has not even been passed. SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal first with some of the points made by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). He is concerned that Parliament is to be bypassed by the Bill. He went into some detail about the disallowance of bounty notices. The Government is proposing a `fast track' method of introducing bounty assistance, similar to the way that tariffs are introduced. We are not proposing a bypassing of the Parliament. I draw the honourable member's attention to clause 10 of the Bill, which provides for bounty notices to be subject to disallowance in the same way as regulations. I am sure honourable members opposite will acknowledge that this procedure, which has been in place for many years, preserves Parliament's ability to scrutinise legislation without imposing inordinately upon its time. Of course, it will be said that it does place a heavy responsibility on members of the Opposition to raise matters that they think need to be ventilated in the Parliament. If that is not done, the responsibility is very largely theirs.

I regret to say that members opposite do not appear to have read my second reading speech with the careful scrutiny that it deserved. That is a cause for concern. I referred several times to Parliament's ability to disallow bounty notices and to the need to introduce bounties quickly. There have been some delays in the introduction of bounties in the past. Those delays have placed burdens on local industry, which had to continue to compete with imported products while waiting for the assistance. If I can give a couple of examples of such delays, it took eight months to pay Kelvinator Australia Limited on its production of room air conditioners and there was a delay of about five months in paying the Commonwealth Steel Co. Ltd on its production of steel products. This caused cash flow problems and the industries were critical of the delay. The `fast track' method will speed up the process. On the other hand, the procedure for tariffs allows them to be introduced immediately. The Bill therefore proposes a similar procedure for bounties to that applying to tariffs, and I believe that the procedure will certainly be welcomed by industry.

The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) noted that the disallowance right of Parliament does not allow for partial disallowance. It is acknowledged that the disallowance right applicable to regulations does not permit partial disallowance at present. The Government is reviewing whether or not there should be partial disallowance of regulations, and this might equally apply to bounty schemes. It is also noted that disallowance, as it applies to regulations, does not permit recovery or removal of rights from the date of commencement of the regulation; rather, only from the date of the disallowance. This Bill, however, will allow on disallowance recovery of bounty paid from the date of commencement of the bounty scheme, where both Houses of Parliament deem that appropriate.

In regard to appropriation, the honourable member is under the mistaken impression that the scheme will appropriate moneys for the payment of bounty under the scheme, again claiming that this would bypass Parliament's crucial role in appropriating moneys. The honourable member should be aware that clause 54 of the Bill specifically requires bounty schemes to be funded from moneys appropriated by the Parliament on an annual basis unless their appropriation is specifically permitted by the Parliament as a standing appropriation from Consolidated Revenue.

The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) asked what industries would be nominated to receive an appropriate bounty. As he will understand, this will go through the Industries Assistance Commission mechanism, and the IAC will be recommending industries for bounties. It will be done in an arm's length way, as in the past. I think the personal assistance given by the honourable member for Denison to Australian industry is applauded by all, although I must say that I was stunned to learn that he was buying so much from the mainland. I assumed that his purchasing policy would be `Buy Tasmanian first'.

TALK.START.PARA: —All bought in Tasmania.

—All bought in Tasmania but not Tasmanian made. It is true that to a large extent, it is up to this country, to determine its pattern of demand. There is a rising enthusiasm for a `Buy Australian' policy. If that policy were adopted generally, we might not need the high levels of assistance which appear to be necessary. However, I think that many of the concerns about industry not being able to compete will be met by the Bill. We will be able to provide immediate assistance by bounty, as we already do by tariff. Industry will not have to wait for the assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is a certain lack of realism in what the honourable member had to say about the history of Australian industry. Manufacturing employment in Australia reached a plateau in 1947, with just one-quarter of the labour force, and stayed there for virtually two decades. With high tariff protection and under the forceful leadership of Sir John McEwen in various trade ministries between 1949 and 1971, Australia pursued a line of import substitution, obtaining rights for products which had originated overseas and making them here, while concentrating export efforts on developing our abundant raw materials.

Under `McEwenism' manufacturing employment reached its high point in 1965, with 27.6 per cent of the labour force. McEwenism was politically popular in its time, strongly endorsed in the electorate and supported broadly by the labour movement, because of its short term job creating potential. However, in retrospect, McEwen can be seen as the architect of our present manufacturing malaise, and the formulas which seemed so appropriate in the 1950s and the 1960s became increasingly anachronistic in the 1970s and thereafter.

Sir John was a frankenstein who created an increasingly helpless monster. Australian industry was programmed not to specialise and not to excel in particular areas of expertise except in the one area that the honourable member for Ryan nominated sotto voce earlier on. We were encouraged to become mere assemblers, duplicating products designed by people cleverer than ourselves. Australian management has to develop industrial strategies of its own and to employ inventors, researchers and technological innovators who can do the sorts of things that other small nations such as Switzerland and Sweden have been able to do.

As the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) pointed out, while McEwenism, as it applied to mineral development, actually worked out very well for us in the 1950s and 1960s, when the whole pattern of world trade started to change and when there was a demand for different types of goods-goods that we were not very good at producing-our share of world trade declined very significantly. I thank honourable members for their contribution to the debate, and I trust that the measure will receive the support of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation Amendment Bill comes before the House at a time when the Government is spending a record amount on the delivery of health services. Under the Australian Labor Party the health portfolio has rocketed to the lead as one of the really big spenders of taxpayers' funds. The Department of Health now ranks No. 2 behind the Department of Social Security as the biggest spending department. Not only has the Government broken all records in increasing government expenditure in this area, but also the rate of growth in expenditure continues at an uncontrollable and alarming rate. This year alone the rate of increase in medical, hospital and drug expenditure is likely to be around 70 per cent higher than was provided for in the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The real disaster is that, whilst the Government's health policies are absorbing more and more of the taxpayers' dollars, the standard and quality of service being provided are getting worse and worse. The record rates of government expenditure have been matched by record increases in the number of people waiting for urgently needed hospital beds. Only those who can afford to pay private health insurance premiums over and above the high rate of taxation and the Medicare levy have guaranteed access to hospital treatment when they need it. Pensioners, the unemployed and low income earners are all now consigned to a long queue when they need hospital treatment. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) stands condemned for imposing a Medicare health policy which is costing more and more and at the same time has allowed the standard of service to decline so that, tragically, those most in need of government assistance for health services are being denied that assistance. Little wonder that polling indicated that health issues are the second greatest issue of concern for Australians today.

There are two fundamental reasons why we are paying more for health care and getting less. Firstly, the Government set about strangling the private health insurance market and private hospitals by substantially increasing the cost of private health insurance. Whilst forcing people to give up private cover, the Government has failed to provide an effective health care delivery system in the public sector to cope with the increased demand. The results have been that we are now paying more through an enormous government bureaucracy and the standard of service has declined. In other words, the Government is in the process of gradually replacing a lean, efficient, competitive private health delivery system with an expensive, bureaucratic, inefficient government health delivery system.

The second significant reason why we are paying more for health and getting less is that the Government has instituted a system of reimbursement for medical services which encourages fraud and overservicing. When the present Minister for Health was in opposition he used to criticise the then Government for fraud and overservicing and he promised to fix those problems. In Government, far from fixing existing the problems he has exacerbated them. Fraud and overservicing are now major contributing factors to the uncontrollable blow-out in the Medicare budget.

The Minister started by doubling the staff and the amount of money allocated to the fraud and overservicing section of the Department of Health. About a year later he said the section was over-bureaucratic and he decided to transfer the function to the Health Insurance Commission. During the recent Senate Estimates Committee debate I proposed questions as to whether the transfer was in fact working and how much money had been recovered in the area of overservicing. I have now been advised that the answer is nil. In the first half of 1985-86 the HIC employed some 217 people at a cost of just over $4m to stop fraud and overservicing. During that period, in the area of fraud they stopped payments worth $325,000 and recovered $48,000. In the area of overservicing they recovered nil. So for every dollar spent on the detection of fraud and overservicing only 9.5c is being saved. With this sort of government investment, no wonder the country is going broke.

I refer particularly to overservicing. It is a national scandal that, instead of preventing overservicing, the Government has encouraged it and at the same time has been unable to recover any money from those who are at fault. Under the bulk billing or direct billing system doctors are encouraged to send the account for medical treatment directly to the Government without the patient being required to audit the account. The Government claimed that its central computer system would be able to identify doctors who defrauded the system or who provided more services than appropriate, considering the medical condition of the patient. This was to be achieved by the setting of parameters on the allowable number of services to be provided in particular circumstances. What, in fact, has happened is that some unscrupulous and unethical doctors have taken advantage of this system by maximising the number of services provided per patient, so maximising their income regardless of the patient's medical condition. An example would be of a patient presenting to an unethical entrepreneurial doctor with, say, a cold. Instead of a general practitioner consultation and perhaps a prescription being written, the person may be referred for pathology tests and maybe radiological tests and perhaps even off to a specialist. Instead of the cost of the visit being around $20, it could easily be $300. The patient, of course, thinks that all this extra attention is wonderful, especially as he has no interest in the bill and would not even see the final bill if the doctor does as he has been encouraged to do by the Government-that is, send the bill direct to the Health Insurance Commission for payment.

The Government has claimed that it would be able to pick up such overservicing. However, clearly it is not doing so. Not only has the Health Insurance Commission been unable to recover any money for such overservicing, but also attempts to prevent payments being made to doctors for such overservicing have not been effective. This is highlighted by the fact that the cost of medical services is running at about $130m over that budgeted by the Government. In my view and that of the Opposition, whilst the Government maintains an open-ended direct billing system for all patients there will continue to be enormous incentive for the unscrupulous, unethical doctor to take advantage of the system. It is totally irresponsible of the Government to allow the continuation of this system, which encourages a rip-off of Medicare.

Claims by the Minister that the Health Insurance Commission is able to pick up such overservicing are patently false. Not only does the rapid explosion in the medical benefits bill highlight the fact that the system is out of control, but also very serious claims have been made that the system has been infiltrated by those who seek to milk it. There are two ways in which information may be being leaked from the Health Insurance Commission. One way is by ex-employees-and we know that there are ex-employees now in the employ of entrepreneurial medical professionals-and the other way is that there is a mole or a number of moles in the HIC advising those who wish to take advantage of this system of the extent of overservicing they can undertake without being detected by the HIC computers. Recent claims regarding a mole were not immediately referred to the Australian Federal Police as one might expect. In fact, it was only after six weeks of continual pressure from myself, together with my referral of the statutory declarations and other information regarding these claims to the Director of Public Prosecutions, that the Government finally referred these matters to the Federal Police.

There is an urgent need for an immediate independent inquiry into the operation of the Health Insurance Commission and its ability to control fraud and overservicing. No doubt the Government will refuse that. It will refuse to undertake such an independent audit of the system and the security arrangements pertaining to the system because it knows that the system itself is fatally flawed. There is no way the Government can guarantee, and the Minister has consistently failed to guarantee, the security of the existing arrangements. The payment mechanism provided by the Government is so open to abuse that it is no wonder that the HIC policing section is totally incapable of controlling this bureaucratic monster. The result has been that the cost of medical benefits has gone through the roof. The Government is allowing some unscrupulous and unethical doctors to have a feast on the Medicare system. The taxpayer is being saddled with higher and higher tax bills to pay for the Minister for Health's ideological commitment to a national health scheme which he cannot control. Meanwhile, those who seek public hospital treatment when they need it are unable to obtain it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am discussing the Health Legislation Amendment Bill which is before the House. This Bill purports to implement amendments to the Health Insurance Act to curtail fraud and overservicing in pathology. It also reduces the fee payable to pathologists for certain tests. Some years ago pathologists and others approached the Government expressing concern that there were some elements of their profession who were abusing the system. The Public Accounts Committee investigated medical fraud and overservicing in pathology and towards the end of last year the Committee made some 41 recommendations for reform. In light of the concern of pathologists and the Public Accounts Committee report, the Government thought it should be seen to be doing something and so it said it would introduce legislation in this session. So here we are in the dying days of the Autumn session of Parliament and the Government has rushed in legislation without consultation with the Australian Medical Association, the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia or other pathology organisations which have often expressed their concern and the need for government action. In addition the Government has not responded to the Public Accounts Committee recommendations, nor is this legislation a satisfactory response to those recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I believe the majority of pathologists warmly welcome the accreditation provisions of this legislation, there is a deep concern that this Bill will not stop fraud and overservicing in pathology. Why has the Minister failed to consult with those in the profession who have been urging legislative change to restrict fraud and overservicing; why has the Minister failed to pick up a large number of the PAC recommendations, especially those supported by sensible elements in the pathology and other medical professions; and why did not the Minister draw up this legislation in consultation with the pathology sub-committee of the Medical Benefits Schedule Review Committee? This latter Committee is under the control of the Minister, and is chaired by an officer of the Minister's Department and its function is to advise precisely on matters covered by this legislation. That Committee has been working on these issues and its detailed report was due to be presented to government within the next couple of months. Regrettably this whole episode is yet another example of the gross administrative incompetence of the Minister for Health.

Only today the Society of Pathologists in Private Practice issued a Press release from which I will quote. The society said that its members were disappointed that there had been no consultation with the profession by the Federal Government on controversial amendments to pathology services. The Press release then referred to the PAC report and its recommendations and said:
Some of these would be much more effective in controlling fraud and overservicing than the legislation currently before the House.
The Society's Press release said later:
Unfortunately-
referring to the legislation-
the planned controls will do more harm to ethical practitioners who perform tests according to the patient's needs than to money-hungry operators they are designed to catch.
The pathologists finished by saying:
The Society remains opposed to fraud and overservicing but does not believe the current legislation is the most efficient or effective way of curbing abuse.

That quotation was from the Press release of the Society of Pathologists. The Minister only deigned to see the Royal College of Pathologists last Friday. The legislation had been introduced; it was to be debated today; yet the Minister only deigned to see the Royal College of Pathologists last Friday. There is absolutely no excuse for his failure to consult with the profession and it highlights the depth of division between this Minister and those who are providing these services under his control. This is yet another step in the alienation of the providers of health care from their Government.

The Bill has six major areas of interest and I shall refer to each of them. Firstly, the Bill purports to tighten the rules regarding those who can be an approved pathology provider or authority under the Health Insurance Act. Undertakings are required to be given by those seeking this status and any breach of those undertakings can be referred to a medical participation review committee whose membership can now include a pathologist.

The second area covered by the legislation is the introduction of the accreditation of pathology laboratories and the limitation of the payment of medicare benefits to pathology services performed in such accredited laboratories. This move has been warmly welcomed by pathologists as a means by which it is hoped that a high standard of pathology practice can be guaranteed throughout Australia. In the States where no State accreditation authority exists, the Commonwealth, through the national association of testing authorities, in conjunction with the Royal College of Pathologists, will undertake inspections.

The third major area dealt with by the legislation is the attempt made to prohibit pathology fee splitting and other forms of abuse. The Bill defines allowable pathology services as those which are necessary, not excessive, performed in an accredited laboratory owned by an APP, by or on behalf of an approved pathology provider. The Bill also prohibits reassignment of Medicare benefits and seeks to provide a more effective deterrent to fee splitting and to limit the improper activities directed at generating additional pathology services, whilst specifically prohibiting bribery or other inducements which are designed to generate additional pathology services. We shall have to wait to see whether these changes are effective and, whilst we certainly hope they are, we are concerned that as a result of the lack of consultation with pathologists, who themselves seek to address these problems, the Minister may not have introduced the most effective measures that he could.

I refer the Minister to clause 47 of the Bill, which makes it an offence for a pathologist to invite additional tests. I presume the Minister does not intend this section to impact on the real role of a pathologist, which includes advising general practitioners. For example, if a patient presented to a GP with anaemia, the GP may order a full blood examination. The pathology report on that examination might say: `Severe anaemia confirmed, bone marrow biopsy advised'. In other words the pathologists would be providing to the GP a means of identifying why the patient is not making the right number of blood cells. I invite the Minister to respond to this point by giving an undertaking that the normal, accepted and ethical roles of pathologists is not intended to be and will not be put at risk by the application of this clause.

The fourth area covered by the legislation is the establishment of the Pathology Services Advisory Committee. This committee will replace the existing pathology sub-committee of the Medical Benefits Schedule Revision Committee. The new Committee will be responsible for recommending the listing, delisting and changing of items on the fee schedule as well as setting prices for such items. The Committee is made up of a Chairman, who is a Deputy President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, three other medical members, and three other members nominated by the Minister.

The AMA and other medical authorities believe that the technical, detailed, medical issues to be dealt with by the Committee ought to be dealt with by specialists in the field. In addition, they are concerned about the fragmentation of the fee setting process with the appointment of this special Committee to set fees for pathology, because to do so for every specialty could lead to a chaotic fee setting process. The Minister has not substantiated his claim that the proposed Committee will allow a more rapid and flexible approach to a wide range of fee related matters than the old pathology sub-committee which was under his control and chaired by an officer of his Department. Given the lack of explanation by the Minister and the concern of the profession, we shall closely monitor this Committee's work. One of the concerns, as I said, is that the medical issues dealt with by this Committee should be considered by specialists in the field. The proposed committee could have a majority of non-medical members, depending on the discretionary appointments the Minister may make.

The fifth area I want to deal with under the Bill relates to a number of minor amendments. The legislation will allow Medibank Private to use an agent to invest excess funds. The Bill provides for an increase from $1.7m to $2.8m in the amount payable to the States for the transfer of nurse education from hospitals to colleges of advanced education. The Bill also extends the Sex Discrimination Act to various health legislation. This will extend the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to de facto spouses of pensioners and concessional beneficiaries at a cost of around $700,000. We will not be opposing these amendments.

The final area of the legislation to which I want to refer is the revision of the pathology fee schedule. The Government has moved to reduce the fees for common pathology tests by 25 per cent, resulting in savings to the Government of between $46m and $47m. The Minister puts forward a number of arguments for this fee reduction. Firstly, he says that a lower hospital pathology rate applies to the tests performed in public laboratories. Generally the rate is 50 per cent of the specialists' pathology rate for these 18 items. The Minister then claims that this means there is an excessive profit component when the tests are billed at the specialist rate. That depends on whether the fees charged by these public laboratories is or is not subsidised-in other words, does it properly reflect the cost of capital, the building, the equipment, and depreciation as well as the full costs of all the recurrent inputs such as labour and materials? I have my doubts about the Minister's comparison and I challenge him to table details of the exact cost of performing these tests in hospital pathology laboratories so that a bona fide cost comparison with respect to the fee schedule can be made.

The Minister also said that by international comparison the specialist pathology rate is unreasonably high. He then compares New Zealand fees with Australian fees, which indicates either the depth to which he is prepared to sink in order to try to sell this proposal, or alternatively his inability to comprehend matters economic.

TALK.START.PARA: —He could not run a corner store.

—That is probably right, too. Given the blow-out in the Medicare budget, perhaps it is the latter. His comparison of pathologists' fees in Australia with pathologists' fees in New Zealand completely ignores the differences in the standard of living, wage structure and so on between the two countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister then argues that the 18 tests involved in this fee reduction are high volume, and mainly automated. The Minister also claims that the tests are highly profitable because fees have not been adjusted downwards with the introduction of more productive technology. Let me then review some of the 18 items which are going to be cut by 25 per cent. Items 11-11, 11-12, 11-14 and 11-16 all relate to cross-matching of blood for transfusions. This is entirely a manual operation, very labour intensive and very often done in small batches after hours. The present fees are considered by reputable pathologists to be generally inadequate and there is no reasonable case for reducing them. Items 16-33 and 16-34 relate to blood cultures. They are not automated and not done in very large volume. They require individual processing by hand. I do not have time to go through all the items, but it is quite clear that the Minister's arguments are fallacious.

The Minister claims that reducing the fees for these particular pathology tests will remove a significant financial incentive to excessive servicing and other abuses. The Minister of course does not point out why the unscrupulous, unethical practitioners will not just redirect their efforts to more lucrative tests, or increase the number of these tests ordered to make up for the lower fee. Under universal bulk billing those intent on abusing the system are likely merely to change their ordering regime.

The Minister took this action at a time when he was due to receive a report from the pathology sub-committee which had reviewed these issues and was to recommend changes to the schedule of fees, including a reduction in a number of fees and changes in some of the other fee arrangements. Some of the reductions in fees that were going to be recommended by that sub-committee have not been picked up by the Minister. Instead of picking up the recommendations of that expert group, the Minister has taken an arbitrary decision to cut these 18 schedule items. In so doing he will impact on the honest and ethical pathology providers, whilst it is likely that the unethical and unscrupulous will merely redirect their efforts.

This is not the way the Opposition would have handled this issue. We would have sought the expert advice of those in the field and we would have sought detailed consultation with the profession. Nevertheless, we are not a government in exile and we cannot rewrite the fees schedule. We cannot do that from the position of opposition. Whilst the arguments put forward by the Minister do not support the proposed changes, we accept that some changes are necessary. Therefore, in view of our concern and that being expressed by the Royal College of Pathologists, the AMA and honest and ethical pathologists around the country, at the conclusion of the debate we will seek an undertaking from the Minister that the proposed reductions in these schedule fee items will be the first issues considered by the new Pathology Services Advisory Committee.

In conclusion, this is a fairly detailed, complex and technical piece of legislation. It has been drafted without the consultation of the profession and there are grave doubts as to whether it will achieve its goal. We will not oppose the legislation. Nevertheless, we will closely monitor its implementation, especially the work of the Pathology Services Advisory Committee, and the impact that the new fee schedules have on pathology practice. At the heart of the Opposition's concern about fraud and overservicing is the Government's encouragement of such practices by the promotion of universal bulk billing. The Opposition will act immediately to stop this Medicare rip-off by restricting direct billing to pensioners and other health care card holders. The country cannot afford to continue to carry the burden of this Minister's corrupt health system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very proud to support the Health Legislation Amendment Bill. Rather than criticise the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), I congratulate him for responding so quickly to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, and for the consultations he had with the Committee during the drafting of its report. He appeared before the Committee. In my six years as a member of parliamentary committees I have never had such a co-operative Minister to work with, nor has such a rapid response to a parliamentary committee report. I thank the Minister for that. (Quorum formed) Before I was interrupted I was congratulating the Minister for Health on his timely response to the Public Accounts Committee's report on overservicing and fraud. While I am handing out bouquets, I think it also important that we acknowledge the work of members of the sub-committee of the Public Accounts Committee, some of whom are in the chamber at present. I would like particularly to extend the thanks, I am sure, of the Minister to the following members of the sub-committee: The honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer), the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and Senators Georges and Watson.

SPEECH.PARA: The recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee's report have been accepted almost in toto. The Minister responded very quickly to those recommendations because he saw, through the Committee's report, the extent of the problem of fraud and overservicing in the pathology area. The report, which was tabled only a few months ago, revealed what a big business pathology is-worth over $300m a year and growing every year. That has to be of concern to members of this Parliament because that is the money of the Australian taxpayer. So the Government has an important and legitimate role in supervising the expending of that money. The 236th report of the Public Accounts Committee that was tabled in this Parliament really pioneered work in the pathology area and outlined for the first time a profile of the area. It showed the concentration in the pathology area of a great majority of money being spent on a small number of companies. For example, it showed that in the first quarter of last year 25 groups received payments of $44m-in just three months. When broken down further, the figures reveal that seven groups received $23m in payment through the national health system. Honourable members can see why it is important that the Government take a strict supervisory role in how that money is being spent. Again, we must congratulate the Minister for Health on acting on this report.

The report identified a number of problems in the pathology area. First of all, it pointed out the changing nature of the pathology industry and the move towards entrepreneurial medicine. The Committee was not critical of the move towards entrepreneurial medicine per se, but it profiled the industry to point out the movement of large amounts of money into a few companies. Big is not necessarily bad, but when money is being directed into such a few hands it is even more important that the Government take a very careful watchdog role.

The report also dealt with the difficulties and the deficiencies in the Commonwealth's administration of the approved pathology practitioner scheme, the medical benefits schedule and other responsibilities related to the Health Insurance Act. In its report the Committee provided insights into the nature and concentrated structure of the pathology industry and discussed the consequences of entrepreneurs infiltrating the industry. It critically analysed the approved pathology practitioner scheme, examined the dominance of the high value specialist pathology payments over other ordinary low value benefit payments and recommended the immediate review of all pathology practitioners and their laboratories. All of those major recommendations have been dealt with in the legislation before the House tonight. That is why the Minister is to be congratulated.

I will deal with only a couple of areas but I think that they are critical recommendations of the report. The first one is the approved pathology practitioners scheme. Before the legislation becomes law any person can become an approved pathology practitioner for $10 providing that he or she employs a medical practitioner. It is not a difficult procedure. One can post a form and for $10 one can get that status providing one employs a medical practitioner. Before this legislation comes into force, tests can be performed in laboratories without any supervision from approved practitioners. Honourable members can see that it would be physically impossible to actually supervise a lot of the tests. Table 7 in the PAC's 236th report analyses the top 25 pathology groups. They are the ones to whom the great majority of health benefits payments are made for pathology. The Committee wrote to everyone of those companies and asked them how many full time and part time specialist pathologists they employed. It is fascinating to look at the figures. Only four of them employ over 15 pathologists; one 22; one 17, one has 18 and another has 22. The great majority of the rest of them either employ one, five, seven or three: it is round about those figures. Let us remember that these are the companies-there are seven of them-that are getting up to $44m in just three months. Because of the number of full time pathologists employed it is physically impossible to supervise the tests. That was one of the key criticisms that the Committee had of the way the approved pathology practitioners scheme worked.

The legislation, which is fairly complex, states that only medical practitioners or currently approved medical scientists can be eligible for APP status and a pathology service must be rendered by an APP or, if rendered on his behalf, it has to be under his personal supervision. What we are trying to do is define what is meant by `personal supervision'. In other words there has to be a reasonable level of personal control and I think that is absolutely critical to reform in this area. Also the service may be provided only in response to requests from a treating practitioner or another APP in writing or orally confirmed within seven days. Only the APP who renders the service can claim for that service either by assignment or by patient billing. This will eliminate the current practice of APPs referring tests to other APPs and claiming for those services. There have been all sorts of rorts in this industry. These changes enforce and specify the responsibilities of the practitioner APP into also determining the necessity of tests.

Persons applying for this special APP status will be subject to stricter provisions than those that presently apply. As I have said, at the moment one just has to fill in a form and away one goes. The Minister will not accept an application from a person who has breached any of the undertakings. An APP's undertakings will be subject to annual review and an annual fee. So there will be much closer supervision. When the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) spoke on this matter he was critical of the Minister for Health for not consulting sufficiently with the pathologists. However, it is my understanding that the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia supports this legislation before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fee cuts?

—The fee cuts are an issue for the Government but the details, the new changes within the industry, have been the subject of considerable consultation with the College. For example, the Public Accounts Committee has been investigating this matter for four years. For four years we have had consultation.
—We have known about it for ten years.
—If the previous Government knew about it for 10 years why did it not do something about it when it had the chance?
—Why didn't you do something about it three years ago if you knew about it?

—I will tell the honourable member why we did not do anything about it. We were not aware of the problem. The Public Accounts Committee's 236th report is the first time in Australia's history that the extent of the problem has been revealed. The reason for that is that it is the first time we have had proper records, which we have been able to get through the health insurance system we have now set up. I hope all honourable members have read the first chapter of this report. It is probably one of the most enlightening and informative documents ever to come before this House. For the first time it has shown the nature and profile of the pathology area.
—It does not recommend fee cuts, though.
—Obviously the honourable member has not read the report. The recommendation by the Committee that has been taken up is very important.
—They welcomed it. I agree with that.

—I am glad that the honourable member welcomed it. Why did the previous Government not do something about it, if the Opposition says that everyone knew there was a problem? It has taken the Minister for Health to do something about the matter and respond very quickly to this report. When honourable members opposite were in government they would never reply to most of the parliamentary committee reports. This Minister has taken the report seriously and acted quickly. It must be a record in terms of taking a committee recommendation through from placement before this Parliament into legislation.
—Have you only just got here? When did you come in?

—I have been here longer than the honourable member. Let us consider accreditation. Why did we have to have an accreditation system? Obviously, is was essential to provide greater control and supervision over quality in the standards of pathology services. The backyard laboratories, which currently provide very poor quality service, obviously can lead to people's lives being in danger and have to be removed.
—They didn't manage to do that, either.

—The previous Government did nothing about it. We also wanted to ensure uniform minimum acceptable standards throughout Australia. All States, through the Health Ministers conference, support the introduction of the laboratory accredited arrangements, although some States have been reluctant to introduce the necessary legislation, as was the previous Government. So it has taken this Government to put the recommendations into practice. Again I congratulate the Minister. The Commonwealth will now operate the laboratory accreditation arrangements for States which do not have accreditation legislation. The Commonwealth will accept laboratories accredited to States with accreditation legislation, such as New South Wales and Victoria. Only pathology services performed in an accredited laboratory will attract the Medicare benefits. That is what is critical. One can get the benefit only if one delivers it in an accredited laboratory and there is some way of controlling what that service is.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go into any other details, except to return to the first point the honourable member for Barker made about timing and consultation. For the benefit of honourable members who were not present earlier, the honourable member for Barker criticised the Minister for Health on the matter of timing. I could not quite understand the nature of that criticism. I would have thought it would have been a matter for praise that the Minister responded quickly to a committee report which revealed such great faults in the provision of pathology services to patients. Rather than being criticised for timing the Minister, should be congratulated on it. He should also be congratulated, through his officers, for the discussion that has been going on with industry. We have not heard any criticism of the major direction of the report from the College of Pathologists. It has supported it. No doubt there will be some differences between all parties about the fee levels, but it is the role of government to set fees. It is the not the role of the industry to determine what the fee structure should be.

On behalf, at least, of the Labor members of the Public Accounts Committee I thank the Minister for his quick response. In politics one spends a lot of time investigating and inquiring and often one does not see quick action in response to all the time one has put into an inquiry. The recommendations before the House tonight show that the committee system is very worth while, and again I thank all the members of the Committee for their support and assistance.

I think all those who serve on parliamentary committees are aware of the contribution that staff members make, and before I conclude I would like to pay particular tribute to Mr Peter Mason, who was the clerk of the sub-committee looking at this matter. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is generally supportive of the amendments contained in the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 but I would like to advise the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) that it was the present Opposition when in government that formed the fraud and overservicing unit within the Department of Health. If anybody stands condemned for not moving earlier, it is probably those bureaucrats within the Department who were well aware of what was happening within the profession generally, and more particularly within the pathology profession, for not bringing these matters more forcefully to the attention of the government of the day. That is not to excuse my Party and the National Party of Australia in government for perhaps not acting a little earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: We support the approved pathology practitioners scheme amendments, which limit approval to medical practitioners and some medical scientists. We support the approved pathology authority concept. We support the accreditation of pathology laboratories, although I believe that such accreditation could be carried out in a lesser time than the two years proposed by the Government. We support the prohibition of pathology fee splitting and other forms of abuse, and we support the establishment of the Pathology Services Advisory Committee. Personally-the Opposition joins with me-I condemn the Government for its present revision of the pathology fee schedule. This is the stumbling block in this legislation as far as I am concerned. It is unreasonable, it is unfair, and I would even go so far as to say that it is the evil part of this Bill. Let me refer to three of the Public Accounts Committee's conclusions. The first states:
Pathology benefits are a significant and growing segment of Medicare expenditure which should be fully accounted for.
I agree entirely with that statement. The second conclusion states:
There is legitimate cause for concern about some aspects of the nature of the growth in pathology benefits, services and providers pre and post Medicare.
The third conclusion of the Public Accounts Committee to which I want to make reference states:

The Medicare fees for many pathology services may be inappropriately high, judging by the substantial discounts (e.g. 40 per cent) offered by some private laboratories to other Approved Pathology Practitioners.

The operative words there, in my view, are `may be inappropriately high'. It does not state, straight out, that they are inappropriately high, but that they may be. One of the Committee's recommendations states:

The procedure for revision and monitoring of the Medicare Benefit Schedule be regularly reviewed to ensure that changes to the Medicare Benefits Schedule are timely and responsive to allegations of widespread abuse, and reflect cost reductions which stem from the development of technology which underlies many Medicare Benefit Schedule items.

There is no doubt that there should be regular review of many Medicare benefits schedules. I do not think there is any doubt that there has been some abuse right throughout this nation not only of pathology services that are provided but also of medical services that are provided for which Medicare benefits are claimable. I do not think anybody would disagree with cost reductions due to technology development, but was the profession consulted, as the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) asked in his speech? The clear answer is no, the profession was not consulted about these fee reductions. Was a survey made of private laboratories? The clear answer is that no survey was made of private laboratories. Has the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) ever visited a pathology laboratory? I know that he has been invited to Queensland to visit one of the largest laboratories in Australia, and he has not taken up that invitation.

Was a time and motion study carried out? Obviously, the answer is no. Were overheads of private laboratories considered? The honourable member for Barker made reference to these points. Were the cost of the provision of facilities-the buildings in which the laboratories are situated-the cost of the expensive equipment that is used, all the leasing costs and the total scene that is involved in the provision of pathology services considered by the Minister when he decided that the 18 most commonly used procedures were to receive a Medicare fee reduction of 25 per cent? The clear answer is no. I shall tell honourable members why those matters were not considered. Had the Minister and his Department considered them, he probably would not have had a case to slash those fees by 25 per cent across the board for all providers of services in this country. The clear answer to all of these questions is no.

It is a very shoddy case indeed that the Minister puts forward. He has not substantiated his case for cutting fees by 25 per cent. What he has done is think of a figure-that figure is about $50m-and said: `I want to take $50m off the pathology bill on the Medicare benefits schedule. That would reduce the total fees payable by the Commonwealth, which amount to approximately $400m, by 12 1/2 per cent or thereabouts, and that is the figure that I will determine. To achieve that, I have to take 25 per cent off the Medicare payments for those 18 most commonly used services'.

The ethical providers-there are a number of ethical providers in this country; I hope that the Minister acknowledges that-are being lumped together with the fraudulent operators and some of the entrepreneurs. The Minister ought to have directed his attention to the entrepreneurs, particularly the fraudulent entrepreneurs who have sprung up over recent years in this country. I turn to the second reading speech of the Minister. He quoted from the Public Accounts Committee report. He then said:

. . . that there was data showing that at the time they were contacted by a PAC member, few of the top 25 pathology groups in Australia had many full time specialist pathologists on staff. Part time specialist pathologists were associated with 60 per cent of them.

The operative statement in that quote is that few of the top 25 pathology groups in Australia had many full time specialist pathologists on staff. The word `few' must mean that some did have, but others did not. The Minister went on to say:
. . . the specialist fees for those 18 pathology items appear too high . . .
On what basis did the fees appear too high? The Minister said that it was because the professional premium is far more than can be justified by the specialist's professional input. He said:

There is also evidence that the fees for the 18 tests, for which there is currently an HP rate, are too high. The costs for some laboratories involved in undertaking these tests are covered by the HP fee, which is currently only 50 per cent of the specialist rate. This means that there is an excessive profit component where they are billed at the specialist rate.

Let me return to the Minister's statement that there was also evidence. I ask the Minister: What concrete evidence does he have-I hope he will answer this question when he responds at the end of this debate-that fees for the 18 tests that are currently charged at the hospital rate are too high? He went on and said:
The costs for some laboratories involved in undertaking these tests-

What an outstanding deduction it is that because some laboratories, to use the Minister's words, are getting the hospital pathology fees, which are 50 per cent of the special pathology rate, those receiving the SP rate are making an excessive profit. What absurd nonsense this is! I ask the Minister whether he or his Department carried out a survey of pathologists to confirm or deny how many full-time specialist pathologists were employed and whether he inquired whether these HP fee recipients were cross-subsidised by full fees or involved in other tests. After all, there is a lot of cross-subsidisation; a lot of propping up by the commonly used services and the claiming for those services with other services that are used infrequently.

I ask the Minister: Did the Public Accounts Committee recommend fee reductions? I ask him to point out specifically where it recommended fee reductions. I submit to the Minister that fee reductions will have little or no effect on savings but will harm the health of thousands of patients. I assure the Minister that the exploiters will continue on their merry way. Let us make no mistake about that: The exploiters will soon see that those doctors who refer patients to them will refer more items that are not included in the 18 most commonly used services.

I ask the Minister: Why was there not a 10 per cent or 20 per cent reduction in these fees, or even 33 per cent or 50 per cent? Where did the Minister get his information from to substantiate the 25 per cent reduction in fees for the 18 most commonly used tests? That is the question that the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Barker, put to the Minister and I think he should table that information for the information of this House, the nation and all those ethical pathologists who operate around Australia. Did the decision to reduce fees by 25 per cent result from the base cost of public hospital pathology services for in-patients and exclude all collection costs and other overhead costs applicable to private practitioners? This is a serious situation and demands a full disclosure by the Minister.

Unscrupulous practices have been in operation, are in operation and will continue in the future, but why are fee reductions necessary? If a practitioner has not been involved in unscrupulous practices, for donkey's years he has been overpaid for those services. Is that what the Minister is saying? Obviously this is nonsense. There are good and bad operators in every area. There are good and bad pathology operators. But with a broad brush of fee reductions all, good and bad, are being treated as unscrupulous. I ask the Minister whether he is prepared to face some of those ethical, professional pathologists eye to eye and to say: `Yes, you have been doing the wrong thing by the system; you have not been playing the game'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He hates them.

—He hates them, as the honourable member for Denison has stated. I turn my attention now to the Queensland operators, because two of the largest operators of pathology services in this country are Queenslanders. The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) implied in her speech that because an operator is large he must be doing something wrong. That was a definite suggestion in her speech.
—That's not right.

—As the honourable member for Moreton has said, just because an operator is large it does not mean to say that he is bad or wrong. The two largest operators in this country happen to be Queensland firms which operate throughout Queensland, offering services in country areas, and in northern New South Wales. In terms of turnover and services to individuals they are the largest in the nation. Big is not necessarily bad or unscrupulous, but that is the obvious connotation that the Minister and the Government are placing on big-big is bad. I reject that concept out of hand.

SPEECH.PARA: Fees should be increased or decreased in a rational way, after proper analysis of all facts. This 25 per cent reduction is ad hoc crisis action by a stupid Minister in a crisis-ridden, incompetent government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Death.

—Dr Death, as the honourable member for Denison says. It is a government that is taking Australia towards-to put it in the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-a banana republic. I suggest to the Minister that he ought to have waited until his advisory committee got under way to review the fees, and not made this ad hoc decision. But no, the Minister wants to save $47m-and he wants to do it now; he does not want to wait and see whether it ought to be saved through fee reductions. He just wants to get it now-probably because he has kept the rest of the specialists and general practitioners in general medicine throughout the nation happy recently by announcing some fee increases, and so he must find the money. Probably the banana republic Treasurer has said to him `Find that extra $60m that you have provided for the profession generally', and the Minister for Health has said: `Yes, I will get it for you, Treasurer, and I will get it by cutting the fees that are going to pathologists'.

SPEECH.PARA: The two Queensland firms to which I refer are Queensland Medical Laboratory and Drs Sullivan, Nicolaides and Partners. They, incidentally, agree with the general thrust of the recommendations. Indeed, representatives of those firms of pathologists have been advocating changes to the system for many years. The Public Accounts Committee recognises that many pathologists are doing the right thing by the system. Indeed, I think that the Minister would agree that both of these firms are squeaky clean. They are playing the game by the rules. They are not ordering services unnecessarily, and they state emphatically that they will not order services unnecessarily. They are professional and ethical firms. There are about 40 professional pathologists involved in both of these firms.

As I have said, the changes will save the Government $47m-it will pull $47m out of the industry at once. That is what this Government is doing. In an industry of about $400m annually, there is to be a 12 1/2 per cent fall overnight. In my view, governments must be more responsible than this. The Government should have directed attention to the problem areas, but what it is doing is throwing the baby out with the bathwater.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again.

—Again, as the honourable member for Moreton states. The Government is saying that these across-the-board cuts will affect the ethical and the legitimate operators. That is less than satisfactory. The entrepreneurs will still flourish. As I said earlier, they will have ordinary GPs and specialists refer them patients for tests other than those included in the 18 most commonly used tests for which the Government has now reduced the fees by 25 per cent, just with the stroke of a pen-with no detailed investigation, no consultation with the industry, and no taking into consideration the profitable and unprofitable services that some of these pathologists provide. One can draw an analogy between the actions of this Government in relation to pathologists and these savage cuts in pathology fees, and the abolition of entertainment expenses and the introduction of the fringe benefits tax. Quite similar situations exist. What we have seen here in relation to the restaurant and catering industry and the fringe benefits tax is that circumstances have developed over many years, indeed decades, and yet overnight this Government, without consideration for individuals in business and industry who have built up practices and businesses over many years, has decided on these measures.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister for Health whether he would like to have purchased a restaurant recently, perhaps, for $100,000, or $500,000, only to find that its turnover had halved or dropped to an even greater extent than that, and whether he would like to have had the introduction of the abolition of entertainment expenses only to find that his particular business was worth a fraction of what it was when he purchased it. We have that clear analogy in regard to what this Government is about. It is about hitting business. It is about hitting pathologists, hitting restaurateurs, and hitting people who are producing in the nation, producing the taxes. The public generally and business in particular should expect more from their governments than the stroke of the pen that we see and the overnight changes that occur.

I wish to refer to the Minister. Earlier I asked him how he would like to be running a pathology practice at the moment-that is, a pathology practice that was run ethically and professionally, in accordance with the rules that have been set down by this Government and previous governments, in situations that have been allowed to develop for years and years. Suppose he was following established practices, charging fees for essential work, not overservicing or being involved in any unethical or fraudulent practices at all. How would he like to have some ivory tower, self-righteous Minister for Health overnight slash fees by 25 per cent for the 18 most commonly used services? I would like the Minister to answer that. In effect, these cuts will reduce pathologists' turnover by about 12 1/2 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I stand here tonight debating the Health Legislation Amendment Bill, I think about the speech we have just listened to by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). In the past he has told us about the extraordinary costs of Medicare and how the Government should be saving money. Tonight the Government has come to the House with a proposal which will bring about a significant change to pathology services in this country-a change which will cut some of the fat from those services and save the Government some money-yet we hear objections from the Opposition. Of course, the fee reductions are not included in this Bill, but certainly the thrust of the legislation will bring about changes in the industry which should remove any financial incentives that existed in the past. Indeed, we have heard from the shadow Minister the suggestion that unscrupulous and unethical doctors will again take advantage of this legislation in order to feather their own nests. It seems to me that he has a very poor view of the profession. Clearly, in the past the structure of pathology fees has been such that it has allowed a considerable amount of fat in this industry and there is a need to trim that fat. The suggestion by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) that because that fat has always existed it should be allowed to continue is absurd.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly it is important for us to look at the decisions that are being made by pathologists. Many of them are very important in the cycle of health costs. They affect the subsequent treatment-whether it be drug therapy, surgery, further investigations or further pathology services-and many other forms of therapy are contingent upon the sort of decisions pathologists make. A great deal of training, skill and expertise is required in the pathology profession. The amendments which relate to the provision of pathology services will reward that skill and expertise while taking away some due to the cost efficiencies that have been brought about by technological change and advances in the development of productivity in that industry. The Government has a desire to improve the payment of medical benefits for pathology services and its concern has been that in the past there have been practices within the industry which, in our opinion, were less than desirable. That was confirmed by the Public Accounts Committee, and its report pointed to various forms of concern. Indeed, there was a belief that the schedule was too complex and that payments were too high. Relativities and comparisons with overseas experience indicate that. Certainly there have been significant technological changes in pathology and the encouragement of entrepreneurial practice has been one of the aspects of this high payment.

The relationship between doctors and the pathological services has been a matter of concern. Inducements and financial interests were matters that were studied by the Public Accounts Committee. On top of all that, the per capita consumption of pathological services has been growing year after year. Therefore, I would suggest it is reasonable and appropriate for the Government to look at fee reductions in particular areas. Because of productivity developments and technological change and because the old structure had not been reviewed and the old structure of fee assessment had not been successful, it was quite reasonable that a small group of services and items-18 in fact-which were highly profitable, often automated, often done in multiple series and requiring very little involvement of the pathologist, should be looked at very closely. Fee reductions have occurred in those areas. It is important to remember that this legislation sets up a fee setting machinery that will be in place to effect adjustments to the schedule and allow adjustments to occur in that schedule if, in the future, those changes that have been made are seen as being unreasonable.

Only the other day I listened to a representative of the pathologists on the radio and he said that he agreed that many of those services had been overly profitable, but his concern was that other procedures that were within the schedule were deficiently rewarded. Indeed, if the schedule needs to be reviewed and if it is not right, we should correct it. But it is not the case that those loopholes and advantages that presently exist should underpin the industry. This fee setting machinery which will be set in place is an important part of that review process.

The cornerstone of the new arrangements within this Bill is the approved pathology practitioner scheme. This part of the Bill defines the criteria that will determine the eligibility and conduct of approved pathology practitioners. As the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) outlined, it is important that the eligibility, supervision, assignment of benefits and review of undertakings of pathology be scrutinised. Within this Bill and within the establishment of the new scheme for approved pathology authorities all of these procedures and matters will be taken into consideration. There will be a yearly review. The corporate structure of such authorities will have to be established. Approved pathology practitioners will have to oversee the activities of such authorities. Indeed, there will be appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Medicare participation review committees will be able to assess any breaches which occur.

Within the legislation there are a number of other measures. Item 955, which is venepuncture, for which general practitioners have received a small benefit under the schedule, has been removed. I think it is true to say that in the past this has provided a financial incentive for doctors to take blood samples and to send them along for pathology. Very often these procedures were undertaken by a nurse. So it is a reasonable and fair measure, I would imagine, for venepuncture to be deleted from the schedule. Certain pathologists' determinable services in the past have been under scrutiny. Again, within this legislation it will be within the powers of the Minister, in co-operation with the College of Pathologists, to restrict such self-determining services. I see no difficulty with that.

The accreditation of laboratories, of course, is something that the Opposition supports. It seems to me that this is overdue. It is necessary for us to control standards and quality within this country and indeed the qualifications of staff working within laboratories are important. The decisions people make in these laboratories very often decide life and death matters for patients. Certainly they decide subsequent therapy, so it is important that this accreditation structure should be established.

Finally, the establishment of a Pathology Services Advisory Committee is the aspect of this legislation which, for the pathologists, is the most important in determining how their schedule pans out in the future. We plan to set out a new and separate schedule for pathology services. This will allow us to establish the two aspects of pathology services-that of fee levels and that of technological information-under the one roof. It will allow oversight of movements within the schedule. The Pathology Services Advisory Committee, with that evidence and with that information, will be able to respond to those changes that occur within the schedule, respond to technology, respond to improvements and relativities and, with consultation with the industry, I imagine we will have a schedule which much more closely represents the sort of schedule that should exist in pathology.

As I have said in the past, there have been significant changes in the structure of pathology in the undertaking of tests. Those changes have brought about some significant increases in the margin for pathologists. It is reasonable that the Government should take those changes into account when striking what it sees as a reasonable fee for pathology services. This legislation sets up a structure to establish a realistic fee setting mechanism for pathology services. It is clear that the relativities of the past have got out of kilter. This legislation will provide an environment to assess and determine the worth of pathology services. These very skilled and dedicated doctors will be fairly rewarded according to their skill and the tests they are undertaking. They must take the responsibility for making important decisions, and the judgments they make are based on their skill and knowledge. I am relieved that we are now finally implementing a structure that will provide a fair remuneration, that we can be fair on the taxpayers, who after all are footing the bill for pathology services, and that we can be sure that the high standards within this industry will continue. I commend the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whenever we discuss the subject of health these days, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) studiously avoids any reference to the fact that the introduction of his socialistic approach to health is the root cause of many of the problems. TALK.START.PARA: —He is not a real doctor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. Although this Bill consists of a number of Parts, I wish to concentrate on Parts II and IIa, which propose to amend the Health Insurance Act 1973 in the following ways: First of all, by curtailing fraud and overservicing in the area of pathology services; and, secondly, by reducing certain payments to pathologists.
