SPEECH.PARA: Before dealing with these matters in detail, I indicate some support for the concept of accreditation. I believe that concept is also supported not only by pathologists in Queensland but also by the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia. In fact, the point was made by Professor Herdson, President of the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia, when speaking on the submission the College made to the Public Accounts Committee, that all medical laboratories should be accredited. This is a major item, because in the Minister's second reading speech some 12 of the 17 pages are directly related to it. Even if I and other people did not think it important, the Minister certainly thinks that it is a major issue in this legislation. As I indicated earlier, Queensland is different. In Queensland we have two major pathology firms-Queensland Medical Laboratory and Sullivan and Nicolaides and Partners-as well as a number of smaller regional firms, some situated in Brisbane and some in the major coastal cities. The major firms provide services to a geographically dispersed area with a low population density and, therefore, their collection costs are quite substantial. I should indicate that those collection costs are nowhere supported or individually funded under any part of the medical benefits legislation.

Queensland Medical Laboratory and Sullivan and Nicolaides are two of the largest firms in Australia, with some 40 specialist pathologists. These are not some of those fly-by-night firms which so concern the Minister; they have highly qualified professional, ethical pathologists. They also have about 1,800 members of staff, many of whom are tertiary qualified, with science degrees and post-graduate qualifications. As the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) said earlier, those firms have been described in numerous places as squeaky clean. That was true even after the Public Accounts Committee's investigations of the pathology industry. They provide a high quality service. They have none of the hidden subsidies that State and Commonwealth laboratories have. They have no subsidised equipment, no subsidised collection service and no subsidised employment practices.

In Queensland, the effect of this legislation-the effect of the Minister's wishes-will be a reduction in the specialist pathology fee. This reduction will have the following effects: First of all, it will affect the pathologists' services to patients in both the city of Brisbane and the country areas, since collection, which is already difficult, will be made more difficult and even less economically viable. Secondly, it will reduce employment in these pathology firms as they have to reduce costs in order to cope with the extra impost imposed by this legislation. Finally, like all situations, if we reduce the returns, we will reduce future investment in high quality laboratories, expensive equipment and in individuals who have to acquire the skills that senior pathologists need to acquire. Australia is already flat out, as the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) has often said, retaining its best scientific brains, whether in the medical or other fields, and this legislation will compound that problem in the future.

I return to the Minister's second reading speech. Dare I say, as a former professor like the Minister, that if this speech had been submitted as an article to an academic journal it would have been summarily rejected as being poorly argued and because the propositions are totally without any empirical support. Firstly, the premise underlying this speech is fallacious. One cannot argue logically that because some entrepreneurial pathologists and medical practitioners exist and charge inappropriate fees all pathologists charge inappropriate fees. That is simply logically not true. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) in his speech seemed to make the same assumption, which is basically false. Secondly, the empirical facts are wrong. I will return to them in a moment. Thirdly, the response of slashing the specialist pathology rate for some 18 items is inappropriate. It is a socialist knee-jerk reaction to a situation which requires some creativity. I return to some of the detail contained in the Minister's second reading speech. Firstly, at page 6 the Minister stated:
The 18 tests involved are generally:
High volume and mainly automated;
highly profitable because fees have not been adjusted downwards because of more productive technology;
generally involve minimum specialist input;

I intend to deal with these seriatim. Firstly, I deal with the question of high volume, mainly automated tests. This statement is simply not true. I take, for example, item 1014, which is a microscopic analysis of blood fluid, used generally as a test to find leukaemia. The examinations of blood film are generally not automated but are done one at a time by a human looking down a microscope. Some films are examined multiple times. Let us take items 1111 to 1117. That is the general category-not all of the numbers are filled-which relates to cross matching of blood for transfusion. It is an entirely manual operation which is very labour intensive and often is done in small batches after hours. Items 1609 to 1621 are microbiology tests. Cultures have to be grown and tests have to be made to see whether they are sensitive to certain drugs. The tests are not automated but are done in large volume. Items 1633 to 1636 relate to blood cultures. The tests are not automated and are not done in very large volumes; they require individual processing by hand. Items 1668 to 1676 relate to urine culture. The tests are high volume and the fee was reduced previously to recognise this. Again, the tests are not automated.

It must be emphasised that the reductions proposed by the Minister will take place from levels already negotiated by his Department and have been adjusted by independent fees inquiries since then. The current reductions have taken place without any consultation with bodies representing pathologists. The changes are arbitrary, will cause massive economic disruption to highly capitalised organisations and in the future will inflate the risk premiums sought by those who wish to enter the pathology services profession. Of course, some of the tests fit into this area. The MBA test is a very common set of tests undertaken by what is called a SMAC machine-a sequential multiple analysis computerised machine. The critical thing, even in these highly automated, high volume areas, is not simply that as many as 120 tests are run in the space of an hour but that, if the tests are to be run at all, they must have a significant amount of high quality control. Of those I have looked at in Queensland, one in every eight tests run through is a quality control test. Every 48 tests the machine must be recalibrated. As the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) continues to say, these are supervised by highly qualified technicians, who are mostly science graduates in chemistry or bio-chemistry, and they must be able to understand when abnormal or different results come about. When abnormal results come up, they require a chemical pathologist to analyse the results in detail. It is these, the five in 100 that require in-depth analysis and in-depth commentary by a pathologist, which have spread the cost over all the tests undertaken. The Minister should be aware of that in relation to pricing aspects of many other products, where overheads are spread over the production of all items. The MBA tests are simply no different from any other productive service.

The second point made by the Minister was that these are highly profitable services `because fees have not been adjusted downwards as a result of more productive technology'. The honourable member for Perth also addressed this matter in his speech. Unfortunately, he seems to have left medicine some time ago and has not kept up with the politics of his previous profession. This issue was addressed by the Deputy President, Mr K. C. McKenzie, in the 1984 medical fees inquiry. His report stated:

As far as economies of scale are concerned . . . they are probably irrelevant with respect to all forms of medical practice, other than pathology and radiology . . . Accordingly I propose to discount fees for pathology and radiology on this ground. The question is what is reasonable.
He went on further:
I propose to apply discounting of 0.25 per cent . . . That is to the total practice costs.
So this issue was addressed in the 1984 fees inquiry. Then in 1985 Mr McKenzie said this in his summary of the 1985 medical fees inquiry:

I turn to the proposal in respect of economies of scale in radiology and pathology specialties . . . the material before this Enquiry relates solely to pathology and not to radiology and even in respect of pathology does not provide a basis on which further discounting could fairly and reasonably be applied.

So, contrary to what the Minister said in his statement, the issue of fee reductions had been addressed specifically by fee inquiries, and since the 1984 and 1985 inquiries there have been no substantive changes in technology in the pathology area.

The third point of the Minister was that generally the tests `involve minimum specialist input'. That comment was extended later in the Minister's statement to imply that the SP fee should apply only when a specialist pathologist personally supervises in detail the performance of the tests or personally performs it. This is an incorrect interpretation of the basis for the SP fee. The SP fee was never intended to have any such connotation. It was introduced to recognise general economic factors involved in pathology services. This is clearly stated in the report of the Pathology Services Working Party, at paragraph 77 on page 29, which I quote:
The two levels of Schedule fees were a general recognition of: Economies of practice, differentiating . . . Firstly: those private practices predominantly engaged in referred pathology-
that is the case with those about which I am talking-
Secondly: the levels and nature of tests in patient episodes, as between patients outside recognised hospitals, and patients of recognized hospitals-
And thirdly-
the expensive equipment and staffing provided exclusively for the practice of pathology by those in specialist pathology practice.

It is absolutely clear that the SP rate was introduced to reflect general economics, not the personal supervision of pathologists. I should also add at this stage that consultation after the tests have been carried out is an exceptionally important part of the service and the two firms that I mentioned earlier, QML and Sullivan and Nicolaides, not only have highly qualified pathologists, but also have world renowned pathologists, one of whom was my former colleague and professor of pathology at the University of Queensland. After-test consultation involves a great deal of time and if general practitioners, who are interfacing with the patients, are to carry out their responsibilities it is necessary for expert advice to be available in difficult areas.
Let me address two other interrelated areas which were touched on in the Minister's second reading speech. The Minister said:
The proposal outlined will have the effect of . . . removing a significant financial incentive to excessive servicing and other abuses.

This simply will not occur. Unethical, entrepreneurial pathologists will simply get around the 18 items that are included in this legislation. The Minister will argue that other sections of the legislation will limit this, but it is easy for unethical pathologists or medical practitioners to order other tests that are not covered by the 18 items that the Minister has hit. For example, they can easily order a folic acid test or a vitamin B12 test or some other item which can be appropriately ordered in the circumstances and which will be charged at a higher rate. This will hurt the professionally ethical pathologists, the ones who do not order additional tests unless they are the deemed tests of which the Minister is well aware. The second point that I wish to mention was touched on later in the Minister's second reading speech. I quote again:
A further proposal contained in the Bill is that requests forms issued by the pathology laboratories for use by referring doctors are to be approved by the Health Insurance Commission.
He went on:
. . . continued approval of forms by the Commission will ensure that any encouragement to medical practitioners to order inappropriate tests should be removed.

The Queensland pathology firms-both of which are ethical firms-already have forms which have been agreed to by the Minister's Department because they happen to combine the request form from the general practitioner and the Medicare assignment form. These make no references to tests, as the Minister would have us believe. In the two Queensland cases to which I have referred tests are ordered by general practitioners with no financial connection with either of the pathology firms. While I agree that it is probably appropriate for the Minister to ask all pathology firms to submit approved forms, the fact is that in Queensland they have already essentially done this.

In summary, this response by the Minister is a typical socialist response. If the Minister really wants to attack the medical entrepreneurs, he must break the financial nexus between the general practitioner ordering the test and the specialist pathologist. This will not be accomplished by this legislation. It will not control pathology tests. It will reduce the services to patients, particularly country patients in areas such as in Queensland. It will penalise the professionally ethical pathologists while doing virtually nothing concrete to retain control over those whom the Government likes to call the entrepreneurs.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 I congratulate the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for its medical fraud and overservicing inquiry and for its excellent and detailed report on pathology. The recommendations in its report form the basis of these amendments to the Health Insurance Act and address the real concerns of the general public and the medical profession to the growing problem of improper practices in the pathology industry. Contrary to what the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) said, they will be effective.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been problems in this area for many years. These problems are not new. In 1977 the Liberal Government introduced legislation to try to control the problems in this area but it did not work. Unfortunately, those few people who have abused the industry have been able to get around these regulations and are still abusing the industry. Our Government has recognised the need to look again for an effective way of controlling these abuses. The amendments in Part II of this Bill are designed to introduce significant new controls over the provision of pathology services and this will greatly reduce the capacity for fraud and overservicing.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts raised a number of particular concerns about the provision of pathology services. I think it is timely to remind the House of some of those. They included a complex medical benefits schedule which encouraged pathologists to perform more tests than were necessary. Payment was too high for tests that were made simple by the introduction of new technology. The prospect of large profits attracted entrepreneurial pathology. Pathology groups provided inducements to doctors to order more tests then were necessary and doctors were found to have financial interests in laboratories which performed their tests.

The cost of pathology services has risen at an alarming rate in recent years. Faced with this situation, the Government had no alternative but to institute more appropriate financial and administrative controls over the pathology industry. The measures being debated tonight will reduce Medicare expenditure by $40m in 1986-87 and by $47m in a full year.

Let us look at what these new arrangements are designed to do. First of all, they will ensure that pathology tests are performed only in accredited laboratories. These accreditation proposals will mean the removal of backyard laboratories which currently provide poor quality services and the implementation of uniform minimum acceptable standards throughout Australia. What is more, the medical profession welcomes this. Even the Opposition welcomes this. Of course, the Opposition is in a bit of a mess when a very sensible measure like this is brought in by the Government. The Opposition finds it very difficult to cope with. One of the difficulties was very evident tonight, but I will leave it to the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), to sort out with the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) his colleague's regret that the former shadow Minister has moved on.

The second effect of this legislation-a related matter which has often been talked about tonight-is the reduction in fees which will follow for automated high volume and highly profitable services. The reduction brought about in the regulation of these fees will more accurately reflect the true cost of these tests. The Government believes that, by reducing the profit margin on these high volume tests, it will also reduce the incidence of kickbacks and other unethical practices.

There has been a substantial shift in pathology to billing at the specialist premium rate, which returns the highest benefit to the pathology provider. In just five years the number of pathology services at the SP level increased by 111.5 per cent-from 8.08 million to 17.09 million; as if that did not have to be addressed. It is clear from evidence to the Public Accounts Committee that there has been a major shift to payment of medical benefits at the highest specialist rate and services provided by private laboratories have grown faster than those provided by hospital and public laboratories. Under the new arrangements, the Government will reduce the specialist premium, introduce a new other pathologist rate and increase the hospital pathology rate, which will involve a 12 1/2 per cent rise in HP fees for public hospital pathology services.

The third effect of the amendments will be to set up a separate Pathology Services Advisory Committee to be established under an independent chairperson. The functions of that Committee will be to review pathology items and fee levels and make recommendations to the Minister for Health. This means that the Advisory Committee will be accountable to the Government, and also that from 1 August 1986 pathology items will no longer be subject to medical fee inquiries, which has been the case for a number of years.

The report highlighted some disturbing aspects of the pathology industry, which included the dominance of specialist pathologist benefit payments over other pathologist benefit payments and the nature and oligopolistic structure of the industry. After information received from several pathology groups, including the top 25, the Committee published some general data on the number of specialist pathologists professionally associated with the top 25 pathology groups during the March 1985 quarter. It appeared that few of the large top pathology groups in Australia had many full-time specialist pathologists professionally associated with them during this period; 60 per cent of the top pathology groups had part-time specialist pathologists associated with them at this time. Because the higher specialist pathology fee can be charged if a test is done by or supervised by a specialist pathologist, for most of these top 25 groups most tests they bill at the SP rate may be carried out by others under the `supervision' of a small number of specialist pathologists. There are cases where only one or a small number of full-time specialist pathologists appear to `supervise' many tests billed at the SP rate in different laboratories and locations. Part-time specialist pathologists may be professionally associated with more than one pathology group.

The report states that all witnesses to the inquiry have expressed grave concern about the many serious problems that currently exist with both the administration and the design of the approved pathologist scheme. The criticism from some specialist pathologists is that the current scheme is open-ended-that its potential for membership is huge. It appears that anyone at all, as long as a medical practitioner is employed, can become an approved pathology provider. As has been said earlier in this debate, all one needs to do is to ring the Commonwealth Department of Health and ask it to send out a form which one signs and sends back with a fee of $10. For $10 one can become an approved pathology provider. That means that one cannot carry out pathology but can bill for it. As one specialist pathologist made clear to the Committee, pathologists do pathology in laboratories but ordinary general practitioner providers bill pathology. They do not do it, they send it somewhere else, and that somewhere else could be a place that does not meet accreditation requirements or quality control. Whoever owns the business charges the fee for doing that pathology and the GP then bills the patient for something he does not even do and may not know the first thing about.

Every patient knows what it is like to get a bill from the doctor and then the bills, many of them, from the pathologist. Under the amendment being presented in this Bill this practice will be stopped. The new arrangements will ensure that pathology tests are performed in an accredited laboratory and that Medicare benefits are paid only to medical practitioners who are natural persons and not companies for tests done in accredited laboratories.

The dilemma caused by the overservicing in the pathology area is a dilemma for everyone. It is a dilemma for the Government because of the costs-we pay for the overservicing. It is to be hoped that the actions the Government is taking are sufficient to come to grips with this problem in the pathology field. The Advisory Committee the Government is setting up will constantly review the situation. It is also a dilemma for the medical profession. In their endeavour to practise what is called defensive medicine, many practitioners have been increasing the use of pathology tests as their defensive weapon against possible legal action. And it is a dilemma for the general public, of course, because we as patients must be able to have complete faith in our doctors into whose hands we place our health. The very fact that the Government has found it necessary to introduce these amendments is a condemnation of some sections of the medical profession who are determined to destroy Medicare, but who are also determined to extract as much money as they can out of the system they are hell-bent on destroying.

As many of us have repeatedly said in this House, the Government is absolutely committed to Medicare; what is more, so is the Australian community. I have honestly never been able to understand why the doctors oppose it. They make very secure money out of it. To achieve uniformity in Medicare benefits, throughout Australia, the Government is putting in an extra $112m this year. This will simplify arrangements which have been unequal between the States. It will be more equitable and it will remove the current disincentives for doctors to relocate to less heavily doctored States. It is the doctors who will get the money from this particular scheme.

The cost of Medicare, which is what the Opposition constantly bleats about, is one which the Australian community can afford. It would do well for those on the Opposition side to remember, as John Deeble has reminded us, that we spend only 7 1/2 per cent of our gross national product on national health. It is a public system which covers everyone. In America, which has a private system with big gaps, 11 per cent of GNP is spent on health, and it is a much higher cost. I commend this Bill to the House.

Additionally, for the six months ended 31 December 1985 the HIC has advised me that it has either uncovered or deterred overservicing or inappropriate servicing practices, which saved around $1m. This was through investigation functions and practitioner and claims monitoring. Indeed, one of the advantages of having the investigation surveillance procedures in the HIC is that a whole range of these activities are possible that were not possible for the Health Department, which was forced much more to take the whole matter through the MSCI system. So if we look at the facts about overservicing particularly, we will see that the HIC with a range of activities is having a useful deterrent effect in that field.

A number of specific issues have been raised in relation to this Bill. First of all, the honourable member for Barker raised a question about the meaning of the word `invites' in the amendments to section 129aa proposed by clause 47. The honourable member expressed some concern about that. It is obvious that the word `invites' does not cover acceptable practices such as advice and statements of opinion by a pathologist when providing results of requested tests to a practitioner as to the limits of that particular test in ascertaining the medical condition of the patient and/or the need for the practitioner to consider requesting a further specified test. I think there are also instances in hospitals where interns may have been instructed to perform or request the performing of certain tests. These instances would also not be invitations within the meaning of that provision. I think this meaning should also be obvious from sub-section 129aa (5), which provides that it is a defence to a prosecution under section 129aa that the conduct in question was in accordance with the standards of professional conduct generally accepted by medical practitioners. I hope that will help to clarify that point.

Some concern was raised about the control I would have in relation to the new Pathology Services Advisory Committee. I point out that the power to make certain appointments to the Committee is limited by proposed new section 78d to a choice from nominees put forward by the Australian Medical Association and the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia. The power to remove members is limited to the circumstances outlined in proposed new section 78h. So there is a considerable limitation on the appointments the Minister can make. In addition, let me add that there is a power for the Minister to issue guidelines for the Committee and the Bill provides that these guidelines must be tabled in the Parliament and are subject to possible disallowance. I would, of course, be consulting bodies such as the Australian Medical Association and the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia in drawing up these guidelines. Moreover, the Minister can refer matters to the Committee. Indeed, I propose to request the Committee at an early stage to undertake a full review of all the items and fees in the new pathology services table. That may again answer one of the issues raised by honourable members opposite.

The Committee also has the power to make recommendations on matters without a reference having been made by the Minister. It might choose to do so if a body such as the AMA asked it to do so. There is also nothing in the Bill to prevent members of the Committee being members of other committees or discussing matters outside the Committee, although the Committee may in some cases agree that this not occur. This capacity for outside consultation by members should enhance the Committee's decision-making processes.

I was asked whether a survey was being conducted in relation to settling the fee issues. I have to say that no survey was conducted. A question was raised about the problem of moving to the Pathology Services Advisory Committee rather than using the current Medicare system we have for handling pathology changes. There are reasons for believing that this will be an improvement.

If there are problems, I have indicated that the Government would be prepared to meet any worries the college may have, and, if necessary, make changes in those sections.

Let me turn to the one issue which has aroused, I think, the only criticism in this debate and that is costs. We were influenced in this decision very much by the general concerns expressed by the Public Accounts Committee. One can identify at least three concerns in relation to fees arising out of that Committee. The first concern was that fees were too high for many tests that were made simple by the introduction of modern laboratory equipment. The second concern was that the Medicare benefits schedule was too complex and it encouraged pathologists to perform more tests than were necessary. The third concern was that the prospects of large profits had attracted entrepreneurs into pathology. As part of our exercise we examined fee structures for pathology in a number of other comparable countries. I think that New Zealand is a very good example to look at when looking at fees in a comparable country. When I say `comparable country' I accept that there are some differences in the cost of living in New Zealand but in terms of medical relativities, for instance, the fees paid to GPs in New Zealand are much the same as those paid to GPs in this country. When one looks at the differences in the fees structure between this country and New Zealand, New Zealand would have to be an extraordinarily undeveloped society to explain the enormous differences that occur. The haematology fee in this country is $25.20; at present the New Zealand fee is $NZ7.79. In the area of biochemistry one test in Australia costs $17.20. In New Zealand it costs $2.60. Three biochemistry tests in this country cost $28.50. In New Zealand they cost $6.20. Five biochemistry tests in Australia cost $28.50. They cost $11.40 in New Zealand. Urine cultures in Australia cost $32. In New Zealand they cost $11.22. They are exactly the same tests performed under the same conditions by the same sorts of machinery. Allowing for the exchange rate, the contrast would become even sharper. The difference would be even greater. That is one guide to the extraordinarily high charges for some of these tests in Australia.

In relation to some specific points made by the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) and addressed in some detail, many of the tests he mentioned-for instance, the blood films, the blood cultures and other cultures-are not yet automated tests. However, new equipment is now available which automates them and which is already beginning to be used. Again, most of the tests the honourable member referred to have very little pathologist input. One can go through all those tests and find out that in most cases they have very little specialist pathologist input. Despite the remarks made by the honourable member, I still say that the SP fees he mentioned were at least in part related to the fact that specialists were very heavily involved. In fact, specialist pathologists are involved in very few of the total number of these tests.

In regard to nearly all of the tests the honourable member mentioned and to many of the tests talked about in documents which have been circulated to honourable members, what is not acknowledged is the fact that a great number of them are done in combination. For instance, most blood matching is done in relation to other blood tests. Therefore, the single collection provides not only for these highly automated tests but also for many of the other tests that are done on the same blood. It is important to recognise, as I have said, that a great number of the tests mentioned by the honourable member for Forde are done in association with other tests. One could go through the statistics, which have been carefully looked at by my Department, and find the proportion of tests that are done in association with other tests, therefore very much reducing overhead costs.

What has happened as a result of the very high payments for these tests and the very high profit levels that are possible is that a lot of the surplus money has been used in providing highly competitive advantages to firms. For instance, if one looks at some of the statistics one finds that something like 25 to 30 per cent of the cost comes from collection costs. Extraordinary collection systems have been set up, paid for by the taxpayer, in order to give firms competitive advantages. I do not believe that those costs can be justified. If this legislation leads to some rationalisations in those areas, it will be a very good thing not only for pathology in this country but also for the general Medicare bill.

Much criticism has been made of this Government for overruns in Medicare benefits. This legislation is one very clear and direct way of addressing them in relation to one area of the Medicare benefits schedule where there is clear evidence of excess profitability. I finish by reading a letter from an ethical specialist pathologist running a fairly large laboratory who, I think, exemplifies the very best in the medical profession in his response to these measures. It is a very courageous letter which he has given me permission to read in this House. It reads:
Dear Minister,

Consequent to findings by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts on Medical Overservicing in Pathology, your government is enacting inter alia a reduction in schedule fees of pathology tests by 25% for the most commonly performed tests. There is widespread opposition to this fee reduction by pathologists in private practice. As a specialist pathologist of some thirty years standing operating my own private practice in Sydney, currently employing about 100 staff and serving upward of about 300 doctors, I feel you might like to know that there is at least one pathologist who approves the principle of the measure you propose.

Pathology is a desirable and necessary scientific adjunct to the proper practice of medicine and has until recent years been an honourable profession requiring years of specialized training on the part of both the pathologist and the technologist. But today the profession is seen by the public as an industry motivated by gain, given to unethical practices like overservicing and actual fraud. To the disgrace of the profession there is a big element of truth in this. Now that we have a National Health Service, the cost of medicine is borne by taxpayers, and you act properly as Minister to protect the taxpayer from those abusing the system for their own pecuniary gain. In addition, you are upholding the true cause of medical science and acting to restore public confidence in the medical profession and pathology in particular. Those dedicated to medicine and pathology will support you for doing what the profession has been unable to do for itself.
I look for continuing scrutiny of the effectiveness of the measures to reduce the attractiveness of pathology to the entrepreneur.

If it will be of any help to ascertain the costs of providing a service in a medium-sized, large automated laboratory, or any other purpose, then my laboratory and its books are open to you or your representatives.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) The terms wastage and resignation are often confused in relation to separation from the Defence Force. Wastage is a loss for any reason. `Resignation' is an option, available only to officers, to terminate their appointments prior to attaining retirement age or on completion of obligation of service. Information on Other Rank wastage is therefore not included in the following tables.
Officer resignation rates for each Service by rank for males and females for the 4 quarters to September 1985 are contained in Tables A, B and C.
Historically resignations comprise approximately 75 per cent of separations.

Analysis of wastage trends is based upon comparing the period under consideration to the preceding five year average. The 5 year rate of wastage for officers prior to 1982-83 was 7.2 per cent. It fell markedly to 5.9 per cent in 1982-83, attributed to then prevailing economic conditions. 1983-84 and 1984-85 rates were above the former average and the half year figures for 1985-86 indicate a full year result of the order of 9 per cent.

Separation rates differ between individual Service and ranks for a variety of reasons. For example, for Air Force Officers it is expected to remain high for the next two years because of the relatively high numbers of personnel recruited during the Vietnam War who have completed, or will complete, 20 years service. In contrast, after the manpower rundown due to the aircraft carrier and fixed wing aviation decisions, Navy separation appears to have stabilised.

Current features are the increasing number of junior officers (Captain equivalent and below) who have resigned in recent months as well as Army's continued concern over the number of Majors resigning.

As there is no requirement for an officer to give any reason for resignation, only voluntary data is available to formulate options for remedial action. Informal discussions with intending and recently separated officers have identified perceived fears of loss or detriment to conditions of service, as contributory factors rather than the prime motivation.

The 5 year average for officer resignations in the categories: Percentage of strength by rank, and percentage of total officer strength are shown in the tables, adjacent to the corresponding March 1984 to September 1985 quarterly figures.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Import of Foreign Merchandise, Commodities and Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 13 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What (a) tariffs, (b) quota restrictions, (c) export incentives, (d) bounties, (e) non-tariff barriers and (f) general protective measures has the Minister's Department identified as restricting the import of foreign merchandise, commodities and services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) the relevant tariffs are those listed in the Schedules to the Customs Tariff Act 1982, which generally apply to imports competing with Australian manufacturing industries. The Industries Assistance Commission has estimated in its 1984-85 Annual Report that in 1982-83 for the manufacturing sector as a whole, the average nominal rate of assistance on output was 16 per cent, the average nominal rate of assistance on materials was 10 per cent.

(b) Quota restrictions, i.e. tariff quotas, are a form of import control which provides for goods to be imported, up to a ceiling level set by the Government, at concessional rates of duty. There is no prohibition on the importation of goods outside quota arrangements but where this occurs higher rates of duty apply. Goods presently subject to tariff quota arrangements are

(i) Textiles Clothing and Footwear Quota-Knitted or crocheted coats, jumpers, cardigans, sweaters and tube tops; Knitted or crocheted shirts and blouses; Woven shirts and blouses; Coats and jackets; Trousers, jeans and overalls; Shorts and Male Swimwear; Women's girls' and infants' swimwear; Dresses, dressing gowns, shave coats, kimonos, bathgowns, nightdresses and night shirts; Sets or garments, suits, tracksuits and rompersuits; Male pyjamas; Undergarments for men and boys; Panties for women, girls and infants; Brassieres; Corsets, girdles, panty girdles, corselettes and body suits; Other garments for women, girls and infants; Garments of artificial plastic material of rubber and textile fabrics; Tights; pantyhose, socks, ankle socks and sockettes; Footwear and parts for footwear; Terry towelling, towels and babies napkins; Bed linen; Curtains; Sleeping bags; Cotton sheeting; Woven fabrics of man-made fibre.
(ii) Motor Vehicles Quota-Certain vehicles less than five years of age.

(iii) Developing Countries Quota-Sugar confectionery; Rubber tyres, tyre cases, tyre flaps, inner tubes and interchangeable tyre treads; Twine, cordage, ropes and cables and articles made therefrom; Tarpaulins, awnings, sunblinds, tents and camping goods; Certain made up textile articles, including sunshades, flags, shoe laces etc; Ceramic sanitaryware; Domestic refrigerators less than 200 litres internal capacity; Electric current rectifying assemblies; Domestic electric fans; Certain insulated electric wires, cable bars and strip; Ships and boats not exceeding 150 tons gross construction tons; Frames for spectacles and goggles; Slide and film strip projectors; Loaded cartridges; Chairs; Domestic furniture; Canned ham; Builders' carpentry and joinery; Hot-rolled products of iron and steel; Cold rolled products of iron and steel; Hoop, strip, sheets and plates or iron or steel; Hot rolled alloy steel; Tubes and pipes of stainless steel; Welded tubes and pipes of iron or steel; Seamless tubes and pipes of iron or steel; Bars, rods, angles, shapes and sections of iron and steel; hollow mining drill steel; sheet piling of iron or steel.

(iv) Forum Island Quota-Plywood; Blockboard; Passionfruit pulp and juice; Caribbean pine; Plastic film and bags; Matches; Reconstituted wood; Furniture and parts therefore; Certain woven polypropylene bags.
(c) and (d) Export incentives and bounties do not directly restrict the import of foreign merchandise, commodities or services.
(e) Goods, commodities and services which are subject to non-tariff customs controls barriers include those subject to:
Used, secondhand or disposals earthmoving, construction and material handling machinery and equipment.
Certain used, secondhand or disposals four-wheeled drive vehicles, and
import prohibition, in some cases importation subject to prior approval:
Fish, landed direct off overseas trawlers
Certain seeds of barley, oats, rye

However in general Australia does not use non-tariff Customs barriers to restrict the importation of foreign merchandise, commodities and services for the purpose of assisting domestic industry. There are however, a number of measures in place which may indirectly restrict importation of products which do not satisfy health or other safeguards. These include plant and animal quarantine requirements, standards for the protection of human health and safety, censorship law copyright protection and markings and product labelling requirements.

(f) Apart from the measures already mentioned, there are not considered to be any protective measures over which the Commonwealth has control which restrict the importation of foreign merchandise, commodities and services into Australia.
However the various Australian States and Territories do have a range of measures which may affect the sale or use of foreign merchandise, commodities and services.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Food Research Report

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the CSIRO Division of Food Research report on research for 1984-85; if so, does it contain a section on microbiology and biotechnology which covers irradiation of packaged processed meats.
(2) Does the report discuss a study of the effect of irradiation on the storage life and organoleptic quality of vacuum-packaged corned beef.

(3) Does the study claim that irradiation at 2.5 to 3.0 KGy caused flavour and aroma changes, while significant, were rated by the panel as only slight; if so, how can significant changes be rated as only slight.
(4) Does the report state that products with a stronger flavour and aroma, such as smoked ham, may better mask irradiation-induced organoleptic changes.

(5) Does the word `organoleptic' mean stimulating any of the organs of sensation, susceptible to a sensory stimulus and the quality of being able to make an impression on the sensory receptors of a special sense organ.
(6) Does the word `mask' include in its meaning `to disguise, screen or conceal'.

(7) Does the claim in the report mean that food products with a stronger flavour may disguise or conceal the changes of smell and taste caused by irradiation of the products; if so, will consumers be expected to allow for this factor when consuming irradiated food.

(8) Does he have any information on the possible effects on the senses of smell and taste of consumers if they are frequently changing from irradiated food to non-irradiated food; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The CSIRO Division of Food Research Report of Research 1984-85 does contain a section on microbiology and biotechnology which includes a study on the irradiation of packaged processed meats.

(3) Yes. While in everyday English `significant' can be used to mean large or substantial, in this particular sentence `significant' is used in it statistical sense, i.e., there is a degree of certainty, normally taken as 95 per cent that taste difference will be detected even if only slight.

(7) Yes. The Burgen Report on the Safety and Wholesomeness of Irradiated Foods published by HMSO in April 1986 states that `The chemical changes produced in food by ionising radiation are in general much less severe than are produced by other methods of cooking and heating'. This being so consumers would no more be expected to allow for changes in the smell and taste of irradiated foods than they would in the case of foods processed by well established methods.
(8) No and it is unlikely that any such information exists.
